24 Resolutions A resolution is also a binding measure available to members and Ministers to raise a discussion in the House on a matter of general public interest .
Unlike motions in general the resolutions have been provided in the Rules of Procedure of both the Houses.
Effect of Motions or Resolutions accepted by the House by voting on a motion or a resolution the House declares its opinion about the subject matter and becomes an order of the House .
As far as their effect is concerned resolutions passed by the Parliament fall in the following categories :
Resolutions expressing merely an opinion of the House are not binding on the government .
The practice is that the decisions expressed in these resolutions are entirely dependent on the discretion of the government .
Resolutions adopted by the House in matters concerning its own proceedings are binding and have the force of law .
Their validity cannot be challenged in courts .
Resolutions having a statutory effect - if adopted are binding on the government and have the power of law .
In such a situation should the resolution be treated as a censure against the Government ?
However after the leave of the House has been granted the member may withdraw his motion with the permission of the House .
Notice of no - confidence motion can also be withdrawn by the members concerned by sending letters of withdrawal signed by all the signatories to the notice before the item is taken up in the House .
In that case the tern is not mentioned in or brought before the House .
The Rajya Sabha has no power to consider a motion of no - confidence because the government under the Constitution is collectively responsible to the directly elected Lok Sabha .
A censure motion is distinct from a no - confidence motion.
The motion of no - confidence does not specify the reasons on which it is based but a censure motion must specify the reasons or allegations and it is moved for the specific purpose of सरकार the government for certain policies and actions .
A motion is moved against the Council of Ministers or against any one minister or against some ministers or in protest against any of their policy and the failure of any minister or ministers is खेद by the House .
The motion must be specific and self - explanatory so as to record the reasons for the censure precisely and briefly .
The Speaker ' s decision whether the motion is in order or not for any reason is final .
No leave of the House is required to move a censure motion .

Committee on Private Members' Bills and Resolutions : This Committee of the Lok Sabha consists of 15 members with the Deputy Speaker as its Chairman .
The Committee thus performs the same function in relation to Private Members' Bills and Resolutions as the Business Advisory Committee does in regard to government business .
There is no such Committee in the Rajya Sabha .
The सदस्यो Committee of the members from the sittings of the House has been provided in the Constitution that if any of the two Houses are absent from all the sittings of the House for a period of 60 days without permission from the House .
To facilitate matters the Lok Sabha constituted a Committee of 15 members to consider requests from members to leave absence from the House .
In the Rajya Sabha such matters are considered by the House itself .
The functions of the Committee are to consider all cases received from the members for leave of the sittings of the House ( and ( 2 ) not to consider every case in which the member has been disqualified from sittings of the House .
The Committee also performs such other functions in respect of attendance of members of the House as may be assigned to it by the Speaker from time to time .
A Rules Committee : Each House has a Rules Committee .
In Lok Sabha the Rules Committee consists of 15 members including the Speaker who is the ex - officio Chairman of the Committee .
In the Rajya Sabha the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman are 16 members of the Committee .
Suggestions for amendments or additions to the Rules can be made by any member of the House minister or the Committee itself .
The Committee thus acts as an Ombudsman or Public Grievances Committee .
संसद Committee : Each House of Parliament has individually and collectively some privileges to them concerning certain rights and privileges without which the House and its members cannot discharge their functions effectively and efficiently .
When a question of breach of privilege arises even though the House is competent to deal with it it is generally referred to the Committee of Privileges existing in either House for examination investigation and report.
A Committee of Privileges is constituted usually every year by the Presiding Officers of the respective Houses .
In the Lok Sabha it consists of 15 members while in the Rajya Sabha it has 10 members .
The functions of the Committee are of a semi - judicial nature and it is vested with wide powers .
Although its findings are subject to the ultimate decision of the House it enjoys the latter ' s confidence and its recommendations are seldom rejected.
The Committee plays a vital role in safeguarding the powers and prestige of the Parliament and the members of Parliament .
The Committee on Information Technology and Public Grievances is the Council of Ministers in the House .
To monitor the implementation of such assurances each of the Houses of Parliament has constituted a Committee on Government assurances .
The Committee keeps a regular watch to ensure that the Government implements its recommendations .
Through its reports the Committee has tried to control and regulate the vast discretionary powers enjoyed by the administration with the main objective of protecting the citizens against any excess or abuse of authority .
Late Shri G. V. Mavalankar the First Speaker of Indian Parliament held that the Committee on Subordinate Legislation is the सदन of the duties of the House and keeps the administration within bounds intended by Parliament .
The Committee on Papers Laid on the Table : in every session the government lays before the Parliament a statement संसद reports and papers either in pursuance of constitutional provisions or in reply to questions or to inform the members of Parliament on various matters .
While some of these reports / papers stand referred to various parliamentary committees including the Committee on Subordinate Legislation a bulk of them remain to be examined in detail by the Committee on Papers Laid on the Table which is constituted by either House of Parliament .
In the Lok Sabha the Committee consists of 15 members while in the Rajya Sabha it has 10 members .
The Committee examines all the papers laid on the Table of the House and reports to the Parliament stating delay if any found in its compliance with the provisions of the Constitution under which it is placed on the Table of the House .
Thus the aim of the Committee in general is to enforce parliamentary control in those areas of administration in which it was not until it was formed in 1975 .
The Committee on Welfare of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes has provided in the Constitution of India for various safeguards for the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes and the machinery to monitor their implementation .
The Commissioner of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes कार्यरूप makes regular reports to the President which has been brought into force in order to discuss in Parliament and to ensure implementation of the recommendations made by the Commissioner of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in effect .
The possibility of a close scrutiny by a Parliamentary Committee in itself exercise a salutary effect on the administration .
Many an act of negligence nepotism and waste are not committed for the simple fear that they may be looked into and exposed to public .

For the Indian Legislature the idea of a separate and independent " separate Secretariat was effective in January 1926 1926 when the Presiding Officers of Legislative Bodies . by भाई was set up at the conference of the Central Legislative Body in India organised by भाई .
This was followed by a resolution moved in the then Central Legislative Assembly by no less a person than Motilal Nehru and seconded by another illustrious leader Lala Lajpat Rai on 22 September 1928 seeking the constitution of a separate Assembly Department .
In fact the same resolution became the source of the creation and authority of the Assembly Department .

The name of the department continued to remain the same till 26 January 1950 when with the coming into force of the Constitution of India and the creation of the Provisional Parliament it was changed to the Parliament Secretariat .

His President is the President ; he contains all the executive powers and is used in his name .

But unlike the U. S. President our President is only a nominal or constitutional head of the Executive .
Contrary to this शक्तियों American Presidential system presents a separation of power and the President is the Chief Executive for a fixed term and cannot be dismissed often .
In the U. S. system the President chooses his minister from amongst the common citizens and the ministers are not members of a legislature while in the Parliamentary system the Ministers are from Parliament and remain part of it and responsible to the Lok Sabha .
The Parliamentary system may be said to have given more emphasis to the concept of responsibility for the Executive whereas the Presidential system obviously promotes more the stability of the Executive .

In the American Constitution the fundamental rights were expressed in absolute terms .
But there can be no absolute right to any individual because the rights of each individual are limited at least by similar rights of other individuals .
The American Supreme Court had to discover and identify the legitimate restrictions on fundamental rights .
But our founding fathers decided to incorporate the restrictions within the relevant provisions .
Thus the Constitution on the one hand presents a balance between the rights of the individual and the interests of the society and the needs of the security of the state .
Directive Principles The Directive Principles of State Policy inspired by the Irish precedent are a unique feature of our Constitution .
Most of the socio - economic rights of the people have been included under this head .
However they are said to be not enforceable in courts yet these elements are expected to guide the governance of the country .
They are the ideals set by the founding fathers before the States and all the organs of the State must strive for their realisation .

Before the Forty - second Amendment the only mention of the word 'secular' in the Constitution was in article 25 ( 2 ) where the State had been empowered to regulate or restrict any temporal activity associated with religious conduct .
Obviously here the connotation of 'secular' was' non - लौकिक or pertaining to matters other than purely religious.
The Forty - second Constitution Amendment Act which added the word secular did not attempt to define it .
It was however felt that the addition was only to approve and explain the fact which was believed to have already existed as a basic feature of the Constitution .
The founding fathers tried to provide for the fullest representation by साक्षरता all the vast adult population of the country without any literacy division of income tax or female man .
There is no hereditary ruler and the head of the state is elected by the people for a specified period .
It is usually called the President of the Republic .
Democratic republic therefore broadly means a State with an elected President and a people ' s government .
All citizens are equal in the eyes of law ; there is no privileged class and all public offices are open to every citizen without any distinction based on the caste creed sex youth or community .
Even if India decided to remain a Commonwealth member even after independence it made no sign of or compromise on the situation as a sovereign or as a Republic .
In fact the British Commonwealth was transformed .
In this positive connotation liberty would mean freedom of an individual to act according to his own will .
The freedom of thought creed faith and worship as elaborated in the fundamental rights part of the Constitution must be so regulated as not to endanger the security of the State local interest etc .
The leaders of the French Revolution believed that all men were equal in the eyes of law .
Whether the law protected or punished it must do so without any regard to distinction of birth etc.
Moreover all citizens of the world are equally eligible for achieving all public offices honours and positions strictly according to their capacities virtues talent and ability .
In the context of पुरुष equality does not mean that all men ( and women ) are equal in all circumstances .
There are bound to be physical mental and economic differences .
Finally the reorganization of States under the Constitution ( Seventh Amendment ) Act 1956 abolished the distinction between Part A and Part B .
Subsequently several new States were created namely Haryana हरियाणा Himachal Pradesh . Nagaland . Manipur Mizoram Nagaland गोवा Arunachal Pradesh and Goa .
Union territories ( i ) Andaman and Nicobar Islands Lakshadweep ( 2 ) Chandigarh Dadra and Nagar Haveli ( 4 ) Daman and Diu ( 5 ) Delhi ( 5 ) now known as National Capital Territory ( Lakshadweep ) .
Where India was the old name and it represented the first expression of the consciousness of the unity and integrity of the country India was the modern name by which the country was known all over the world .
As a member of the United Nations also it was called India and all international agreements were entered in that name .
Both the names therefore had strong supporters .
Finally the name 'India that is Bharat " was adopted as a happy compromise .
India is a " Union ; but the purpose of emphasising this fact was to bring into focus the fact that it was not the result of a bargaining or an understanding between the constituent units but a clear declaration of the constituent assembly which possessed its authority and power of India .
No State could therefore secede from the Union nor could it suo संविधान vary its territory as laid down in the First Schedule to the Constitution .
Article 2 provides that Parliament shall by virtue of the statute promote the entry or establishment of new States in the Union of India on terms and conditions which it deems fit .
The latest addition to the Union was through the 35th and 36वें Constitutional Amendments in 1974 and 1975 .
This was done at the request of the Sikkim Assembly and with the approval of the people of Sikkim .
Parliament is empowered under article 3 to form a new State by separating a part of the territory of a State or by uniting two or more States or parts of States or by uniting any territory to a part of any State .
It can increase or decrease the area of any State and can also alter the boundaries or even the name of any State .
There is thus no guarantee of the territorial integrity or continued existence of any State .
But at the same time it has been held that the Parliament ' s power to diminish the area of any State does not include the power of dedicating the Indian territory to any foreign State .
( संघ of trade and commerce AIR 1950 SC का ) ;
It may be said that India is an indestructible Union of राज्यों states .
It represents the individual having full political membership of the State : he is the permanent allegiance to the State and the official recognition by the State of his integration into the political system .
Citizenship provides certain नागरिकता rights . duties and privileges .
All public offices are open to the citizen .
The right to vote and certain fundamental rights are available only to citizens and citizens have obligations like paying taxes defending the nation etc.
Citizenship may also be viewed as the legal relationship between the individual and the state under which the individual pledges his loyalty to the State and the State offers its protection to the individual .
This relationship is regulated by national law and recognized by international law .
On 26 November 1949 the Constituent Assembly adopted the Constitution and at once brought into force articles 5 to 9 relating to Citizenship .
Until then those of us who lived in British India were under the Crown and as such were British subjects .
The partition of India and massive migrations created stupendous problems for citizenship determination .
Citizenship provisions in the Constitution - articles 5 to 11 - gave the Constitution Drafting Committee the maximum headache and took a large number of drafts and more than two years to be finalized.
Still in the Constitution only the law was laid down in regard to who would be citizens of India at the time of the commencement of the Constitution .
It did not provide for the mode of acquisition and termination of citizenship .
Article 11 said that Parliament could regulate the right of citizenship by law .
But under Article 5 - 8 " everyone who had been born in India since the time of the commencement of the Constitution came to be a citizen of India and not more of a citizen was born in 1948 .
Thus Citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution included provisions for Citizenship ( e . ) on the basis of domicile ( पाकिस्तान ) of migrants from Pakistan and ( नागरिकता ) of citizens residing in foreign lands .
Domicile : Domicile is an important criterion for citizenship of a country .
Raza v. State of Bombay . AIR 1966 SC 1966 ) .
Article 5 provides that if any person resident in the territory of India lives at the beginning of the Constitution ( i . e . hell ) on the commencement of the Constitution ( अधिवास ) he or her parents were born in India ordinarily less than five .
Domicile by birth or residence as a person could be changed .
In fact अधिवास citizenship is denoted by domicile and not vice - versa.
The latter is distinguishable from citizenship inasmuch as it is vitally connected with territory and not membership of the community which is at the root of the concept of citizenship ( Abdul Rahman v. State AIR 1964 SC अधिवास ) .
The Constitution avoids dual नागरिकता it is related to the domicile in the territory of the whole of India and not to a part of it .
There is no separate State citizenship of India as in the United States .
The domicile which he has is only one domicile namely domicile in the territory of India .
( Pradeep Jain v. Union of India AIR 1984 SC 654 प्रदीप )
The migrants from Pakistan : Article 6 has been the citizenship rights of migrants from Pakistan before the commencement of the Constitution .
Two types of distinctions have been made among such migrants ( that is July 19 1948 ) when the permit system for migration was introduced in India before the UK and those who came after that date .
The person who had migrated to India from Pakistan before July 19 1948 will be considered as the citizens of India at the beginning of the Constitution provided someone from his parents or as a नागरिक or as a member of the Government of India .
Thus नागरिकता has been considered the future citizenship needs of all Indians residing abroad .
Voluntary acquisition of citizenship of another country Article 9 provides that if a person has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of a foreign State he shall forfeit the right of citizenship of India .
The provisions apply to cases arising before the commencement of the Constitution but in matters arising after the commencement of the Constitution the Citizenship Act . shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of the Citizenship Act 1955 .
The Supreme Court has decided that it is the business of the Government of India to determine whether a person has been deprived of the citizenship of India by acquisition of citizenship of another country and after that no State Government is treated as foreigners .
- LRB - राज्य v. State of Kerala AIR 1966 SC 1966 - RRB - ; पीर ( see Ajay Nath v. State of Kerala AIR 1967 SC 1966 ( AIR 1967 SC 1969 ) and पीर मोहम्मद 1969 ( see interview ) .
Article 10 lays down that every person who is a citizen of India under any of the provisions made in Articles 5 to 10 shall be a citizen of India subject to the provisions of such law as Parliament shall be made subject to the provisions of such law .
In other words it means that a citizen ' s right to citizenship cannot be छीना in any other way than parliamentary legislation .

Parliament ' s power to regulate the right of Citizenship by law and the Citizenship Act 1955 Article 11 endows Parliament with unfettered powers for enacting legislation pertaining to the acquisition and termination of the citizenship of India and all matters connected with it .
Accordingly the Parliament passed the Citizenship Act 1955 1955 providing for the acquisition and termination of citizenship .
Thus all matters relating to the citizenship rights after the commencement of the Constitution are to be dealt with in accordance with its provisions .

The privileges are granted with a view to maintaining the independence of action and the dignity of the Houses of Parliament their committees and members and to enable them to function without any let or hindrance.
The privileges in practice give rise to certain powers immunities and exemptions .
The most important of parliamentary privileges is that of freedom of speech while performing parliamentary duties .
Article 19 also gives a citizen the right of free speech but articles 105 and 194 lay special emphasis on the right of free speech of members of the legislatures .
Under article 19 the right of free speech is subject to reasonable restrictions for instance the law of contempt .
In doing this members should not suffer any inhibition and they should be able to speak out their mind and express their views freely.
Unless whatever a member says enjoys immunity from legal action he cannot be expected to speak freely and उन्मुक्ति .
The Constitution provides therefore that no action shall be taken by any member of Parliament in Parliament or in any Committee thereof shall be taken by any member of Parliament in any court of law or before any authority other than Parliament .
Likewise it would be a breach of privilege to take legal action against him for anything said by him in Parliament or in a Committee thereof .
In the case of नागरिक the Supreme Court has held that the freedom to speak under article 105 would only be subject to the provisions of the Constitution which are subjected to any rules and regulations imposed by Parliament and any permanent orders .
Any investigation outside Parliament for anything said or done by members in the discharge of their parliamentary duties would amount to a serious interference with the members' rights .

The emergence and development of modern parliamentary institutions in the modern sense that of parliamentary government and legislative institutions was a matter of fact connected with British India for nearly two centuries.
It would however be wrong to presume that exact British institutions were at once transplanted to India .

They evolved through a series of struggles for freedom from foreign rule and for the establishment of free democratic institutions and the halt of the British rulers - and gradually रुककर by constitutional reforms .

The Government of India Act 1919 1919 and the rules framed under it made many important changes in the Indian constitutional system .
The first Council consisted of 60 members of whom 34 were elected 20 were nominated officials and 6 nominated non - official members .
The strength of the Legislative Assembly under the Act was fixed at 140 : there were 100 elected members 26 nominated officials and the rest nominated non - official members .
As per the statutory rules the total number could be increased and there were changes in the ratio between the members of different groups : to at least 5 / 7 members of the total number being elected and at least one - third of the remaining .

In 1920 the total electorate for the Council was only सभा and the responsibility of the Legislative Assembly .
The normal term of the Council was five years and that of the Assembly for three years .

It could also extend their normal term in special circumstances .

The Government of India Act 1935 aims at the establishment of a federal structure .
It provided that in the discharge of the functions of the Governor - General he would be required to assist and extend his functions to the notice of the Council of Ministers " or to his individual discretion " .
The Federal Legislature The individual or collective responsibility of the ministers was not mentioned in the Act though every minister was expected to be a member of either House of the Legislature .
He could preside over meetings of the Council of Ministers in his own discretion .
The Federal Legislature was to consist of His Majesty represented by the Governor - General the two Chambers being the Council of State ( the Upper House ) and the House of Assembly ( Lower House of Assembly ) respectively .
The Council of State would be a permanent body not subject to dissolution but one - third of its members retire every third year .
Every Federal Assembly was to continue for five years if it was not dissolved by the Governor - General in his discretion .
Each House was to elect its Chairman and Deputy Chairman and would have the power to regulate subject to the provisions of the सदन Act its own procedure and conduct of business .
The Governor - General will have the power to invite and prorogue the Legislature and to dissolve the Lower House .
No Bill would become law unless agreed to by both the Houses and assented to by the Governor - General or the Bill reserved for the विधेयक of Your Majesty ' s intention .
Even an Act assented to by the Governor - General could be disallowed by His Excellency .
The Governor - General could remit a Bill to the Houses for reconsideration .
In the case of disagreement between the Houses the Governor - General could summon a joint sitting in which decisions could be reached by a majority both the Houses were shared nearly equal powers ; the सदनों सदनों
Money Bills could be introduced only in the Lower House but the Upper House had the power to amend or reject them in the same way as the Lower House the सदन and the Governor - General had the power to resolve the differences by summoning a joint meeting .

The people require an institution possessed of an object and the medium by which they may express and exercise their sovereignty .
Under the scheme of our Constitution and its provision of universal adult franchise the people exercise their sovereign power while voting for the representatives of the Union Parliament .
The Parliament becomes the supreme institution through which the sovereignty of the people becomes manifest .
Initially the Indo - Greek City States and during the Vedic period in India the people themselves assembled together to decide the matters of governance .
People thus exercised their power directly in deciding matters of the state and this kind of polity could be called direct popular democracy .
But with the gradual increase in the size and population of the political system and ultimately with the formation of the modern nation - states it was impossible to arrange for the people to assemble at a place to discuss matters of the State and arrive at decisions smoothly.
All forms of direct democracy therefore soon became extinct all over the world ; except in some Swiss लोकतंत्र where issues could still be decided by the people directly by vote .
Modern democracy has of necessity to be a representative democracy where people exercise their sovereignty through their elected representatives .
The word ' Parliamentary ' is specifically a sort of democratic polity wherein the supreme power vests in the body of people ' s representatives called ' Parliament ' .
It is the pivot which is the foundation of the political system of the country .
The President of the Republic is directly elected by an electoral college consisting of the elected members of both the Houses of Parliament and the elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the States .
Though the President of India is a constituent part of the Parliament he does not sit or participate in the discussions in either of the two Houses .
There are certain constitutional functions in regard to the Parliament which he / she is required to perform and the President invites both Houses of Parliament from time to time .
He can prorogue the two Houses of Parliament and dissolve the Lok Sabha .
Moreover while the two Houses of Parliament are not in session and the President has to be satisfied that conditions exist which makes it necessary for him to have proceeded at once the Bill passed the Ordinance which would affect the power and effect of Parliament .
Besides he has the power to decide after he has received the opinion of the Election Commission whether a duly elected member is subject to the disqualifications laid down in Article 108 of the Constitution .
His decision in this matter is final .
Rajya Sabha : The Rajya Sabha is as its name indicates the Council of States or the Council of States .
The different States of the Union have not been given equal representation in the Rajya Sabha .
Thus while Uttar Pradesh has 34 members in the Rajya Sabha smaller States like Manipur Mizoram Mizoram Mizoram Nagaland Sikkim त्रिपुरा Tripura etc. have only one member .
The populations in some of the Union Territories such as Andaman and Nicobar Islands Lakshadweep Chandigarh Dadra and Nagar Haveli Daman and Diu and Lakshadweep are too small to be represented in Rajya Sabha .
Under the Constitution Rajya Sabha consists of not more than 250 members .

When the two Houses passed it and on August 4 1935 the King appointed it as the Government of India Act 1935 it became the Government of India Act 1935 .
The Government of India Act of 1935 थी 1935 the most remarkable feature of the Government of India Act 1935 was the 'an all - India federation of the Indian States willing to join the British provinces and the Union .
Till the 1930 Round Table Conference India was a completely unitary state and whatever powers the Provinces had were given to them by the Centre .
The 1935 Act for the first time provided for a federal system which would not only include the Provinces of British India but also the Chief रियासतें ' s Provinces and the princely states .
It finally abolished the concept of a unitary system under which British India had so far been administration .
The principle of 1919 constitution was decentralisation rather than association .
Provinces ( i . e . in normal circumstances were free from Central control in that area .
The Act separated Burma from India and two new provinces of Orissa and Sind were created .
Keeping in view the proposed scheme at the Centre the eleven गवर्नरों Provinces were मुक्त except for certain specific purposes ; the सरकार Central Government and the " supervision की of the Secretary of State were completely free of charge " .
In other words the कर Provinces were given a separate legal personality .
Moreover Parliament is empowered to abolish or create a Legislative Council in a State by a simple procedure not involving an amendment of the Constitution .
If the Legislative Assembly of a State passes a resolution of this effect by a special majority it can only be done by an Act of Parliament .
Last but not the least the Parliament exercises some control over the States through the Governor .
As we know the President is a constituent of the Parliament and at the same time the Executive head of the Union .
Governors of states are appointed by him and they hold office during the pleasure of the President .
Moreover the President may make such provisions as it deems fit in the discharge of the functions of the Governor of the State in any contingency not provided for in the Constitution .
All these facts however do not imply that the States in India should be merely administrative agents .
In their own region no one is subject to each other .
In the words of Dr ? the States are as sovereign in the field which is assigned to them by the Constitution .
The scheme of provincial autonomy envisaged by the Act provided for an executive and a legislature in every province .
The Council of Ministers was made responsible to the Legislature and could remove it by passing a vote of no - confidence motion .
The Legislature could exercise some control over the administration through questions and supplementary questions .
But the Dominion Legislature could not accept or reject nearly 80 per cent of the grant - in - aid .
In the legislative field the Central Legislature could pass laws on subjects included in the Concurrent List though in case of divergence the Federal law would prevail .
The federal part of the constitutional scheme under the Government of India Act 1935 was most considered .
The Provinces did not accept the scheme of the Federation and since the conditions of their association with the Federation of the States could not be fulfilled they were created and therefore the Indian Federation of India figured under the 1935 Act could not form a federal Act .

The Secretary - General is the third important officer of the House.
He is the adviser to the Speaker to the House and to the members on all parliamentary functions and activities and in all matters of procedure and practice .
As a permanent officer who is the head of the Table and continues to be the consistent link between the changing various Houses and the सदनों General Secretary is the custodian of parliamentary conventions and traditions and the wisdom of the Houses first सदनों and his own experience .
The Secretary - General discharges in his own right many legislative functions administrative and executive functions and renders services and provides facilities to the members .
He is the overall incharge of the Watch and Ward Organisation and the security in the precincts of the Parliament Estate .
The Parliament Library also functions under it the Library Research Reference Documentation and Information Services .
He is responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the buildings and properties of the Parliament .
As the overall head of the parliamentary Museum and Archives he is the custodian of the heritage of Parliament and the keeper of all parliamentary records .
He is the head of the legislative services and the Secretariat of the House and is responsible for its administration for maintaining discipline and for seeing that the secretarial work of the House and its Committees is organised properly and conducted efficiently and efficiently .
He provides secretarial assistance and staff to all the Parliamentary Committees and is available to them for advice.
Its role is that of a friend philosopher and guide to the members and the Committees .
Members of various political parties approach him for consultation .
To a great extent he has to maintain the same role of impartiality and objectivity as that observed by the Speaker .
He must be fully conscious and लेने or soon निर्याय .
For a person holding the post of Secretary - General it is necessary to be a genius and versatile in the manifold functions of the Parliament which is entrusted to him is of a more technical and complicated nature of all kinds of officials and officials .
The work is organised in such a manner that each unit is concerned with a particular subject or aspect of parliamentary life and is carried out with a body of talented staff who are technically qualified and who discharge their duties efficiently.
It is the duty of the Secretary - General to see that adequate personnel are trained to fill out the gaps occurring from time to time and that the efficiency of parliamentary work is maintained at a high level .
Much therefore depends upon the personality and mind of the occupant of the post of Secretary - General in giving shape and character to the secretarial सदन of the House .
His approach and approach are always absolutely non - partisan and objective .
He is elected from among the officers who have done their commendable job in serving the Parliament in various capacities in the Secretariat of the House .
The Speaker is the authority to choose and appoint him .

He cannot be criticised in the House and his actions in the House or outside the House are not discussed .

13 . The member who gives notice of such a question may ask questions at short notice to brief for asking questions .

Only one such question can be placed in the list of questions on a day .

While a very few bills of non - government members take the form of law they serve a good purpose because they bring to the notice of the government and the people that it is necessary to revise the light of the changing conditions .
Bills can be classified on the basis of their contents as follows :
i original Bills which provide for new proposals ideas and policies ;
Bills to replace Ordinances issued by the President .
In such a case leave of the House is not necessary to pass the Bill .
In other words parliamentary legislation does not have to go through stage of presentation .
( b ) Second Reading of the Bill is the most elaborate and important stage in as it is at this stage that it is examined in detail and minute details .
The second reading or the consideration stage consists of two steps which may be called the first stage and the second stage .
The first stage comprises the general discussion of the whole Bill ; the विधेयक i . e . the विधेयक i . e . on the principle underlying the Bill and its details .
At this stage it is open to the House to refer the Bill to the Select Committee of the House or the Joint Committee of the two Houses or to circulate it to elicit opinion thereon or straightaway take it into account .
To specify a committee a Bill may be referred to a Select Committee or a Joint Committee .
The members of the Select Committee are drawn from among the members of the House where the Bill has been introduced .
In the case of the Joint Committee the members of both the Houses are represented ; in such a case the ratio of members from the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha shall be 2 : 1 .
The Chairman of the Joint Committee is appointed by the Presiding Officer of the House in which the Bill has been introduced .
The Bill again passes through the Committee stage and the Bill is presented as a विधेयक report to the House .
After the report of the Select or the Joint Committee on the Bill is presented to the House the Minister may make any motion which is to be proceeded to determine whether the Bill be referred to or appeared again to the Committee as reported by the Bill .
The controversy then remains confined to the Bill as reported by the Committee and the principles of the Bill cannot be discussed again since the motion for referring to the Bill is adopted the House is committed to the principle of the Bill .
The second stage is the commencement of the clause - by - clause consideration of the Bill or the motion for consideration of the Bill as reported by the Select / Joint Committee .
Each clause is placed before the House separately for discussion .
Immediately after a clause is placed before the House amendments thereto can be moved subject to the conditions of admissibility .
clause wise consideration is often long and difficult as each clause is generally discussed separately and each amendment is also passed either by the mover back from or separate from the House .
Amendments if accepted become a part of the Bill .
In the remaining cases the stages of the Bill are the same as in the case of Government Bills .

The proceedings in Committees are largely conducted in the same manner as in the House but in a more intimate and informal atmosphere and on non - party lines.
When a Committee is विचार a member can speak more than once on a question under consideration .
All questions are determined by a majority of votes of the members present and voting .
In case of an equal division of votes on a matter the Chairman has a second or casting vote .
The Committee drafts a report thereafter on the basis of the कार्यवाही of the sittings of the Committee containing the substance of deliberations of the Committee together with the recommendations.
They can frame their own internal Rules of Procedure subject to the approval of the Speaker .
They normally do not go into questions of policy in pursuance of the fact that policy formulation is the exclusive privilege of the Parliament and a Committee is not supposed to sit in judgement on any policy already approved by Parliament .
In order to avoid possible interference in day - to - day administration the Committees examine only those acts which have already been done or not done which otherwise नहीं

The institutions that we continued after Independence and embodied in the Constitution were the institutions which had धरती on the Indian soil .
The founding fathers on the basis of old institutions which had already grown and known about whom they had become familiar and had hoped to build enterprises despite all the limitations and परिसीमाओं of all kinds .
The Constitution did not alter the British rule but the institutions which had developed during the British regime .

Even after the opening of the Constitution of India on 26 January 1950 the process of its making was continued through its actual working - out judicial and constitutional amendments .
The manner in which and as the people of the people worked from time to time so acquired new meaning .

The Constitution of India is unique in many ways .
It has many features which distinguish it from other Constitutions of the world .

A hostile habitat
The deep sea with temperatures not of light and great pressure is an alien abode to us .
We can expect the life of only a few species there .
When Gordon and his colleagues collected samples from the ocean floor they were amazed by the diversity of animal species there - a diversity that rivals anything found on land and in shallow water .
How do so many species survive in such an adverse environment ?
One can explain this amazing diversity - by principle that constant changes in the environment maintains this diversity .

Citizenship In keeping with their aim of building an integrated Indian fraternity and a united nation the founding fathers provided for a single citizenship despite the federal structure of the Union .
Unlike in the United States there has been no separate citizenship for the Union and the States and all citizens across the country have been covered with all the rights without distinction - only the Kashmir State - LRB - tribal areas - RRB - where certain safeguards are provided .
The 42nd Amendment to the Constitution inter alia added a new Part to the Constitution under the head Fundamental Duties " .
In fact no right can be without corresponding duties and rights of citizens have no meaning without respect for the political obligations of the citizens towards the state .
An independent judiciary has been set up in the Constitution of India .
The High Courts and the Supreme Court form a single integrated judicial structure with jurisdiction over all laws Union - LRB - Union - RRB - State Civil Criminal or constitutional laws .
As in the case of the United States there are no separate federal and State court systems .
It is not only विवादों disputes and functions as the custodian of individual rights and freedoms but it can be expected from time to time to निर्वचन the Constitution and to विधान it for the validity of any law in the context of the Constitution .

On 6 June 1947 at the meeting of the Union Constitution Committee tentatively decided that the Constitution should be a federal structure with a strong Centre and that there should be three exhaustive lists with residuary powers vesting in the Centre .
The Committee unanimous adopted the view that it would not be beneficial to the country that would enable a weak central authority as such authority would not be effective in the way of securing co - ordination in important matters of peace and collective interest and in the international country and not in matters of the manner .
In the context of these developments the Drafting Committee decided in favour of describing India as a Union although its Constitution might be federal .
The emphasis on India being a Union was to convey the fact that it was not the result of a compact or agreement between the constituent units but a declaration by the Constituent Assembly deriving its authority from the people of India .

The distinction made by the Act in the executive and legislative functions of the Governor - General ' s Council resulted in the inclusion of a fourth or legislative member and the appointment of the distinguished legal Lord Macaulay .
Thus we shall see the seeds of a Legislative Council as distinct from the Executive Council in the 1833 Act though it did not have long been utilised .
The Charter Act of 1853 was the final Charter Act of 1853 which made significant changes in the Governor - General ' s Council .
The Council ' s fourth or legislative member was given equal status as other members by the power to attend and vote at executive meetings .
At the same time the Council was enlarged for legislative purposes by the addition of six special members ( including the head of the legislative पार्षद ) .
Thus in addition to the Governor - General and the Commander - in - Chief the Council set up under the Act of 1853 consisted of twelve members .
When the Council served as a legislative body the discussion was not written but spoken ; the Bill was sent to a member instead of being sent to the Select Committee instead of being confidential and public proceedings were कार्यवाहियों
The new council was not only responsible for making its duty legislation but as amended in its Official रहे report ( published in 1918 ) ; unlike the संसद of the Parliament it समवेत its collective entity.
The Indian Councils Act of 1861 : the object of the Act was to make better arrangements for the constitution of the Council of the Governor - General and for the local government of several States and Provinces .
To give a fair extension of the Governor - General ' s Legislative Council it arranged that it would consist of at least ten or at least sixteen " additional members ; the first such provision was to consist of at least twelve members .
Similarly the number of additional members of the Provincial Legislative Councils was also increased .
The regulations under which additional members of the Councils were nominated laid down that some non - official persons should be nominated on the recommendations of certain recognised bodies or bodies representing particular interests .
The Legislative Council of the Governor - General ( गवर्नर ) or the Indian Legislative Council of India consisted of five more members out of which four were nominated by the non - provincial councils and one by the Calcutta Chamber of Commerce .
Although the term ' election was not deliberately used it recommended by non - official members of the Provincial Council and transferred to the Central Council the accepted ' principle of indirect acceptance of the principle of indirect election .
The members of the Legislative Council were also empowered to ask questions ( विधान ) i . e . from a view to eliciting information on important matters .
The right to this right which is an inherent right of any Legislature has been made very rarely at that time but the right to be secured is a decisive step in the संस्था of a parliamentary institution .

Broadly speaking the Indian Legislature had no power to amend or repeal any parliamentary law relating to British India or to do anything affecting the authority of the British Parliament .

Thus under the 1919 Act the Indian Legislature was an independent body and was powerless before the Executive in all spheres of governmental activities in administrative matters legislative and financial matters .
However with the formation of the Dominion Legislature the task of framing of international legislation was not in the hands of the Governor - General ' s Council .
The body had now to function as a cabinet and submit financial and legislative proposals of the government in the Legislature presided over by non - official " अधिकारी .
The legislative activity increased and many new legislations which gave a lasting advantage to the country were enacted .

The duration of each member of the Rajya Sabha is six years ; as many as one - third of its members retire every second year from the date on which the office of the members are notified by the Government of India .

Lok Sabha : The other House is the Lok Sabha the Upper House of the People .
It is directly elected by the people .
Every citizen of India - LRB - not below 18 years of age - RRB - is entitled to vote for the Lok Sabha unless he is otherwise disqualified under law .
The Constitution says that not more than one member of the Lok Sabha shall be elected directly from the territorial constituencies in the States and not more than 20 members shall represent the Union Territories chosen in such a manner as Parliament provided by law .
In addition the President may nominate not more than two members to represent the Anglo - Indian community .
There will be no change in the number of seats in the Lok Sabha by 2000 ( articles 81 ) ; Lok Sabha seats in the ratio of population to the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes are reserved in the Lok Sabha .
If the Executive has almost unlimited power to formulate legislative and financial proposals and place before the Parliament a formal and acceptance by the Executive without any difficulty being created by the Parliament it is open to the notice of the government and to discuss it .
The Executive and the administration are responsible to the Parliament .
The function of Parliament is to exercise political and financial control over the Executive and to ensure parliamentary surveillance of administration .
Parliament has the power to make laws regulating the constitution structure न्यायालयों organisation the jurisdiction and powers of the courts .
The Constitution laid down that the number of judges other than the Chief Justice would not exceed seven .
Parliament was however empowered to determine by law a large number of judges .
Under this provision Parliament passed the Supreme Court ( Number of Judges ) Act under which the number of other judges was increased to ten and subsequently by various amendments to the Act .
Thus at present the number of judges of the Supreme Court including the Chief Justice is 26 .
Each state has a High Court consisting of the Chief Justice and such other judges as the President may from time to time deem necessary to appoint .
There are many authorities who very legitimately interpret the Constitution almost daily during the discharge of their functions .
The basic function of the Courts is to adjudicate disputes between individuals between individuals and the States between the Union and between the Union and the States and while so adjudicating the Courts may be required to interpret the provisions of the Constitution and the laws .
And the interpretation given by the Supreme Court becomes the law honoured by all Courts of the country .
There is no appeal against the judgement of the Supreme Court .
It remains the law of the land unless its interpretation is reviewed or reversed by the Supreme Court itself or the law or the Constitution is suitably amended by Parliament .
If an Act of Parliament is set aside by the Judiciary the Parliament shall remove the defects committed by it for which it has been set aside which it may again be enacted .
The Parliament of India is not as supreme as the British Parliament where no judicial review of legislation is permitted.
At the same time Judiciary in India is not as supreme as in the United States of America which recognises virtually no limit on the scope of judicial review .
The Parliament of India representing as it does all constitutionally organised shades of public opinion at the national level occupies a very important place in the political system of the country .
It embodies and सार the sovereignty of the people ; it is the voice and mirror of the nation .
Members of Parliament as elected representatives of the people ventilate the people ' s grievances and opinions on various issues scrutinise the functioning of the Government and make laws .
The Parliament functions as the संसद संस्था and watchdog of the nation .

The Parliament gets information from various sources in a variety of ways : but the Government is the largest source of information therefore it has to rely very much on the government departments to its information needs from the Parliament and its members .
Parliament ' s right to be informed is unlimited ; except that if प्रतिकूल of any information is likely to prejudice vital national interest or the security of the State it may not be insisted upon .
As far as the activities of the Government are concerned the Government itself is the duty of the Government to provide complete and accurate information to the Parliament from time to time .
This information is made available by the ministers making statements on the floor of the House laying reports and papers on the Table of the House or in the Parliament Library .
All these constitute a wealth of information which is immediately released and can be used to raise discussions in the House .
The most popular and effective mechanism through which members on their own elicit information is that of asking questions in the Houses of Parliament .

The Parliament becomes the legitimate arena for international power struggle for गतिविधि of political activity or for acting out the conflicting roles and interests with parliamentary rules and procedures facilitating eventual reconciliation.
Instead of fighting to annihilate each other the लडाई groups agree to disagree and to accommodate or tolerate each other .
In performing this conflict resolution role the parliamentary institution acts as a great national integrator and mediator in change.
In the context of our highly pluralistic society the role of Parliament which resolves and bring unity is particularly important .
Besides the role played by the formal parliamentary forums and parliamentary procedures attention may be drawn to the Central Hall of the Parliament House which is almost an institution in itself .
Here Parliament secret to all parts of the country irrespective of their caste creed region or religion comes formally and discusses the problems that affect the country personally or groups .
It creates feelings of national unity which cannot be produced elsewhere .
Even those who before entering its portals may have some separatist regional or parochial views get cleansed and all feel one? people of one country .

Rajya Sabha : The Members of the Rajya Sabha represents the people of the States and Union Territories .
They are elected through a system of indirect election and in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of single transferable vote.
After the motion is agreed to by the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha and the Speaker of the Lok Sabha orders of the President to summon the Houses on the date and time specified are obtained by the Secretaries - General of the two Houses .

Normally there are three sessions of Parliament each year namely the Budget Session ( July - May ) the Monsoon Session ( July - September ) and the winter months ( September ) .
In the case of the Rajya Sabha however the Budget Session is split into two sessions with a three to four weeks holiday in between thus resulting in four sessions of a year of the Rajya Sabha .
When the Lok Sabha is summoned to meet for the first time after a General Election the President appoints a member of Lok Sabha as the Speaker pro सभा .

President 's Address After the newly elected members have taken oath or affirmation and the Speaker has been elected the President addresses both the Houses of Parliament assembled together in the Central Hall of the Parliament House.
The President also addresses the Houses together at the beginning of the first session of each year .
The President arrives in the State Coach at the Parliament House where he is received at the gate by the Chairman Rajya Sabha the Speaker Lok Sabha the Prime Minister the Minister of Parliamentary Affairs and the Secretaries - General of both the Houses .
He is then conducted in a ceremonial procession to the high - domed Central Hall of Parliament along a red - कालीन route .
After the National Anthem has been played the President reads the address .
The Address contains details of policies and programmes which the government proposes to pursue in the coming year .
Being a statement of the policy of the government the Address is drafted by the government .
Half - an - hour after the President ' s Address both the Houses meet in their respective Chambers where the copies of the सदन ' s Address are laid on the Table of the House by the Secretary - General .
The President’s Address is discussed in both the Houses on a Motion of Thanks moved by one member in each House and by another .
The discussion on the Address is very wide and any or all aspects of administration are communicated
Members can speak on all sorts of national and international problems .
Amendments to the Motion of Thanks can also discuss matters which are not specifically mentioned in the Address .
The only limitations during the discussion are that members cannot refer to matters for which the Government of India is not directly responsible and the name of the President cannot be mentioned during the debate .
At the end of the discussion usually the Prime Minister replies to the debate on the President ' s Address .
After the Prime Minister ' s reply the amendments to the Viceroy are disposed of and the Motion of Thanks put to vote of the House .
When the motion is passed the notice of the motion is conveyed to the President by the Speaker through a letter .
The President after receiving the suggestion of the Prime Minister through the Secretary - General of the Lok Sabha approves the date for the election of the Speaker .
The Secretary - General there after sends a notice of this date to every member .

Within the House and in all matters connected with the House his word is final.
Independence and impartiality are the two important attributes of the office of the Speaker .
His place is larger than all the ministers in the Cabinet except the prime minister .
His salary and allowances are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India ; they do not have to be voted by Parliament .
His conduct cannot be discussed except on a substantive motion .
He shall not vote in the House except when there is an equality of votes.
2 . When in such a case of equality he gives his casting vote it is always in accordance with well - established parliamentary principles and practices .
When the Speaker is elected he अलग himself from all the activities of his party .
He does not hold any party post ; he does not participate in any party meetings or functions keeps away from political controversies and party campaigns .
He performs these functions in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution and the Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business in the Lok Sabha .
His decision in all parliamentary matters is final .
The Speaker has the residuary powers to issue directions in respect of matters not specifically provided in the Rules .
While doing so he may ask a member or the government to provide documentary evidence and information which he may consider necessary to arrive at a decision .
The Speaker has great powers to govern the functioning of the House in a peaceful and orderly manner .
He can order a member to discontinue his speech or to withdraw words or expressions which he feels are या or या .
He can order that nothing said by a member without his permission shall be included in the proceedings and that anything found पाई be excluded from the course of action .
The words or parts of the speech which have been ordered are not to be कार्यवाही or as सदनों - as the rights of the newspapers are not to be published by the Parliament as the rights of the people are unlimited .
The Speaker may ask any member to leave the House for one day or for any part of the day to go away from the House or to suspend an appropriate motion when there is a breach of disorder .
It is the Speaker ' s duty to keep all the members in discipline and they have to exercise extreme caution in showing their appropriate respect and obeying their decisions .
Whenever he speaks in the middle or rises to propose or raise questions for the purpose of raising a question he makes some remarks or gives his rulings he must be heard in peace .
The Speaker also determines whether there is a prima facie case for a matter relating to a breach of privilege or contempt of the House whether a matter of conduct of a member or the conduct of a member should be referred to a Committee for investigation .
If he does not give his consent the matter does not proceed further .
The statements contained in the House which have defended the honour of persons and would prevent any member from making such a statement if he has not submitted such statements or evidence thereof based on the nature of which they have not previously issued .
The Speaker has to be sensitive to the atmosphere in the House .
He communicates the decisions of the House to the authorities concerned and requires them to comply with the terms of such decisions .
All the Parliamentary Committees of the Lok Sabha are constituted by him or by the House .
They function under his control and direction.
The Business Advisory Committee . the General Purposes Committee and the Rules Committee work directly under his Chairmanship .
It determines what matters are financial matters which fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Lok Sabha .
If he certifies a Bill to be a ' wealthy Bill ' his decision is final .
In case of disagreement between the two Houses on a Bill whenever a joint sitting of the two Houses is called he presides over such a joint - sitting and all the Rules of Procedure in such a sitting operate with its directives and orders .
It is a breach of privilege to reflect upon his impartiality ability.
This is necessary to preserve and retain the dignity of the House ; if a member of the Lok Sabha is arrested in any offence . or sentence of imprisonment is convicted of the Speaker नजरबंद or any such authority is immediately convicted of the Executive .

No person can be arrested nor can a legal process civil or criminal proceeding against him be served without obtaining the permission of the Speaker .

The No - confidence Motion The Council of Ministers holds office as long as it enjoys the confidence of the Lok Sabha .
To ascertain this confidence the rules provide for moving a motion to this effect which is called a No - confidence motion .
There is no clear provision in the Constitution regarding the individual responsibility of a minister to Parliament for anything done or not done in his department .
This responsibility is सामूहित .
Therefore merely a motion expressing want of confidence in the Council of Ministers as a whole is admitted and the one expressing lack of confidence in a minister is not in law .

After ascertaining the views of the government the Speaker decides the date for the discussion .
If the government so desires the discussion can even be started at that time .
The time for the discussion is usually fixed on the recommendation of the Business Advisory Committee .
After the members have spoken usually the Prime Minister himself replies to the charges levelled against the government .
The mover has a right of reply .
When the debate is concluded the Speaker puts the question forthwith and decides the decision of the House by a voice vote or a division if asked for it is called मौखिक .

( a ) Budget is presented in two parts of our Parliament : i . e . in regard to railway finance the railway budget is the general budget " and the general budget " .
The primary idea behind presenting a separate Budget for the railways is to secure stability for civil estimates by providing for an assured contribution by the railways and also to introduce flexibility in the administration of railway finance .
The Railway Budget is presented to the Lok Sabha by the Minister of Railways sometimes in the third week of February every year and the General Budget is presented by the Minister of Finance on the last working day of February at फरवरी .
The Budget is presented with a Budget Speech which is in fact one of the most important speeches in Parliament .
This speech is in two parts : " A " has a general economic survey of the country " and Part B in " is the taxation proposals for the coming financial year .
A copy of the Budget is laid on the Table of the Rajya Sabha after the speech of the Finance Minister in the Lok Sabha .
Soon after the minister introduces a Bill which contains the taxation proposals of the government .
( a ) Discussion on the budget is essentially a body of discussion .
The passage of the Budget is marked by deep and thorough discussions in both the Houses of Parliament .
The discussion on the budget starts after a few days of its presentation .
It gives members full time to study the text of the Budget and to discuss the financial proposals among themselves .
Budget is discussed in two stages : i General Discussion " and thereafter in detail the demands for grants and voting .
Besides opportunity for further discussion on वित्तीय financial proposals arises during consideration and passing of Appropriation Bill and Finance Bill .
( One ) General Discussion on the Budget starts from a general debate which takes place in both the Houses of Parliament for three or four days .
Firstly at this stage members consider only the general aspects of fiscal and economic policies of the Government and do not go into details of taxation and expenditure .
The general debate thus offers an occasion for each House to express its views .
The government may also get an idea as to how a particular proposal will be taken at the subsequent stages .
It may be noted that the Rajya Sabha by virtue of its power has no business with the Budget beyond the general discussion .
( 2 ) Discussion on Demands for Grants and in accordance with the procedure the discussion and voting of demands for grants in another stage .
Normally separate demands are made for the grants proposed for each ministry .
The demands are related to the expenditure part of the Budget and are in the nature of request made by the Executive to the Lok Sabha for grant of authority to spend the amount asked for .
Demands are to be moved in the form of a motion but in practice they are assumed to have been moved ; and are proposed by the Chair to save the time of the House .
During the discussion on demands which is lively the policy and the working of the ministry comes in for close scrutiny .
Time is allotted to each ministry for discussing demands .
It is open to members to disapprove a policy pursued by the ministry or to suggest measures for economy in the administration or to focus attention of the ministry to specific local grievances .
The members can do so by moving a subsidiary motion to the main motion for demands for grants .
These subsidiary motions are called in parliamentary parlance Cut motion .
The Business Advisory Committee fixes a time limit for voting a particular demand and for all demands for grants including the Budget .
As soon as the time limit for any demand is over the procedure for that discussion is implemented and the demand is put to vote .
Likewise on the last day allotted for all the demands for which the demands have not been disposed of so far are put to vote whether they have been discussed or not .
This process is known as ' गिलोटिन ' .
In addition the discussion on demands for grants ceases .
It was realised by the standing committees on Departments concerned that before the गिलोटिन came into force the demands for grant of only two or three या at any given time were discussed.
Set up of 17 departmentally related Standing Committees of Parliament are inter alia charged with the task of considering the demands for grants of the ministries and departments concerned and reporting to the House before voting on the demand .
After the 1994 - 95 demands were presented to the Parliament both the Houses were adjourned for a period of one month to enable the respective Standing Committees to inspect and discuss matters .
During the 1994 Budget Session these committees presented 48 reports on demands for grants for 1994 - 95 .
( c ) Appropriation Bill Under the Constitution no money from the Consolidated Fund of India can be withdrawn without the enactment of law by Parliament .
This Bill as its name suggests is to give the Government a legal right to व्यय expenditure from the Consolidated Fund .
The method of considering and passing an Appropriation Bill is the same in the case of any other Bill except that the controversy is confined to matters which the demands cannot be made nor made during the debate .
After the Bill is passed by the Lok Sabha the Speaker certifies it as a Money Bill and transmits it to the Rajya Sabha .
The Rajya Sabha has no power to amend or reject the Bill and has to give its consent to the Bill .
The Bill thereafter is presented to the President for his assent .
( d ) Financial proposals of the government for the coming year are included in a Bill called the Finance Bill which is ordinarily introduced in the Lok Sabha every year after the Budget is presented .
Discussion on a Bill covers matters relating to general administration and local grievances within the Union Government to :
While general criticism of the policy of the government is permitted discussion on the details of particular estimates cannot be discussed .
In short the whole administration comes under review but questions which have already been discussed cannot be चर्चा .
This Bill has to be considered and passed by the Parliament within 75 days after it is introduced and assented to by the President .
Vote on Account In a democratic set - up the government endeavours to give full opportunity to Parliament to discuss the budgetary provisions and the tax proposals .
The passage of the Budget beginning with its presentation and ending with discussion and voting of demands for grants and adopting Appropriation and Finance Bills generally goes beyond the start of the current financial year .
So long as the Parliament does not agree to the demand it is necessary that the government should have enough money to run the administration of the country .
A special provision has therefore been made for the vote on account " by which the Lok Sabha has been empowered to grant grants for a part of any financial year by the completion of the budgetary procedure .
During an election year if there is an expectation that the vote on account may be taken for a longer period of three or four months if the main demands and the Appropriation Bill are passed by the House .
As a matter of custom vote on account is treated as a formal matter and passed by the Lok Sabha without any discussion .
Vote on account is passed after the general discussion on the Budget is over and the discussion on demands for grants is taken up .
In the case of the Railway Budget which is passed before 31 March no vote on account is taken but if necessary in an election year may be taken .
Supplementary and Excess Demands for Grants No expenditure can be incurred by the Parliament without its sanction .
If the amount granted for a specific service is found insufficient for the purpose of that year or on any new service which is not envisaged in the budget of that year the President may draw supplements or व्यय additional expenses thereof .
If
All cases of such excesses are brought to the notice of the Parliament by the Comptroller and Auditor General through his report on the Appropriation Accounts.
The excesses are then examined by the Public Accounts Committee which makes recommendations regarding their regularisation in its report to the House .
Supplementary Demands for Grants are made to the House before the end of the financial year and is passed whereas the demands for excess grants are actually made after the expenditure has actually been incurred and the financial year is presented after the financial year has passed .
Legislative Procedure Regarding Ordinary Bills ( a ) The preparation of a draft of Bills as soon as any legislative proposal is emerged the ministry concerned shows what its political विधेयकों administrative राजनीतिक financial and other consequences might be .
If other ministries or the State governments are also involved their advice is taken .
Professionals and various interest groups such as business labour agriculture and industry if considered necessary are also consulted.
The Bill is then examined in detail by the administrative machinery in consultation with all the authorities concerned and given a final shape .
After this complete process the Bill is ready to be brought before the House .
It can be introduced in either of the two Houses of Parliament by the minister concerned .
The minister has to give seven days' notice to move for leave to introduce the Bill and two copies duly शुद्ध of the Bill are sent to the Secretary - General of the House in which the Bill is to be introduced .
After the Bill has been found complete in all respects by the Secretariat it is included in the List of Business on a date selected by the Speaker or the Chairman as the case may be decided for this purpose .
Normally copies of the Bill should be made available to the members at least two days before the date on which it is proposed to be introduced .
( 2 ) Three Reading - A Bill has to pass through various stages in the Parliament before it becomes the Act .
Each Bill undergoes three readings in each House ( i . e . reading ) i . e . second reading and third reading .
( a ) First Reading is a necessity for the leave of the House to introduce a Bill .
After the Question Hour on the appointed day the minister incharge of the Bill on being called upon by the Speaker rises in his seat and says " Mr महोदय " I beg " .
The minister stood up and says " Sir I apply the bill " .
Generally speaking विधेयक to introduce the Bill which is the first reading of the Bill is a mere formality and by convention there is no discussion at this stage .
However if the motion for introduction of a Bill is opposed on the ground that the proposed legislation is outside the legislative competence of the Parliament the Chair may permit a full discussion in which the Attorney - General can also participate .
Thereafter the question is put to vote in the House .
There being no restriction on the number of Bills to be introduced on a particular day a minister may introduce as many Bills as he may have .
The bill can be published in the Gazette with the permission of the Speaker / Chairman even before introduction .
These are ad hoc Committees which are appointed to consider particular Bills referred to .

Amendments to various clauses can be moved by the members of the Committee .

Procedure for consideration of a Bill in Committees is the same as in the House .
After the Committee is taken into consideration various sections . schedules etc. and accepted by the newly elected Lok Sabha Secretariat prepares a report for presentation in the House or the Houses .
