It is clear that the framers of the Constitution took Parliamentary Committees for granted and left it to the Houses to provide for them in their Rules of Procedure .
Under the Rules of the Lok Sabha not every Committee consisting of members of Parliament is a Parliamentary Committee suo सभा .
In fact Consultative Committees do not report to anybody but merely provide a forum for informal exchange of views between the ministers and members of Parliament interested in their departments.
They are not parliamentary committees .
Types of Committees There are two types of Parliamentary Committees in India ( i ) the Standing Committees and ( two ) ad hoc Committees .
The Standing Committees are those Committees which are appointed every year or from time to time or are nominated by the House or nominated by the Speaker / Chairman and on matters which are permanent and which the Committees are constituted by the House or the Chairman .
The Standing Committees in each House ( and certain Joint Committees ) may be categorised in terms of their functions :
Their recommendations are intended to tone up the administration for economic efficient and speedy execution of these policies and programmes .
Reports of these Committees have earned for them considerable respect from all sections of the society both official and non - official .
Every recommendation is carefully analysed and processed and the administration always endeavours to remove the faults and lapses pointed out by the Committees and to act in accordance with the recommendations made by the Committees .
The Financial Committees have developed adequate procedures to ensure that their recommendations are given due consideration by the government and where they are not accepted the Committees are apprised of the reasons for their non - acceptance .
The progress in the implementation of the recommendations as well as any unresolved differences between the Committees and the government are brought to the notice of the House by way of Action Taken Report " .
The elaborate and effective procedure for follow - up of the recommendations made by these Committees is essentially an Indian innovation to the parliamentary procedures prevalent elsewhere .
The three Financial Committees are elected by the House for each other .
Ministers can neither become members of these Committees nor can they be asked to appear before them for the purpose of giving evidence .
Their Chairmen are nominated by the Speaker .
Committee on संसदीय In a parliamentary democracy like we have it : there is an inherent right of the people to present petitions to the Parliament with a view to समाधान grievances and seeking redressal thereof and offering constructive suggestions on matters of public importance .
This right is exercised through the Committee of Petitions .
Each House has a Committee on Petitions .
In the Lok Sabha the Committee consists of 15 members while in the Rajya Sabha it has 10 members .
The function of the Committee on Petitions is to examine every petition which after presentation to the House stands referred to the Committee .
The Committee reports to the House on specific complaints made in the petitions after taking such evidence as it thinks fit .
The Committee suggests remedial measures either on the specific case under review or in a general way to prevent such cases in future .
The Committee also considers representations including letters and telegrams received from various individuals and associations which are not covered by the rules relating to petitions and gives directions for their proper settlement .
This Committee has already made its mark in affording parliamentary support to the common man in the matter of redressal of his just complaints .
It has proved to be a real boon to those wronged and oppressed citizens for whom no remedy or relief is available elsewhere .
In the Lok Sabha the Committee consists of 15 members while in the Rajya Sabha it has 10 members .
In order to ensure that there is an effective and continuous check on the possibility of misuse of such power by the administration each House of Parliament has its own Committee on Subordinate Legislation .
The Committee of each House consists of 15 members nominated by the Speaker / Chairman .
The , Committee is reconstituted every year .
The Committee examines them whether suitable provisions have been made to place their rules or orders on the Table of the House .
If the Committee concludes that the provision made in the Bill for delegated powers should be revoked or postponed or amended it may report to the House before the Bill is taken into consideration .
The Committee consists of 30 members ( 20 from Lok Sabha and 10 from Rajya Sabha elected by the respective Houses of Parliament from amongst their members .
The functions of the Committee are to consider the Report of the Commissioner of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes and report to the Parliament as to the measures taken or required to be taken by the government on them .
The Committee also ensures effective implementation of the constitutional safeguards for these backward communities .
( Six ) Service Committees are some of the Committees of the Parliament which look into various kinds of facilities and services provided to the members and other matters concerning the functioning of the members of both Houses of Parliament .
These are the General Purposes Committee the Joint Committee the Library Committee and the Salaries and Allowances of Members of Parliament.
General Purposes Committee : Each House has a General Purposes Committee .
The Presiding Officer of the concerned House is the ex - officio Chairman of the Committee .
It consists of the Deputy Speaker or Deputy Chairman Committees as the case may be members of the Panel of Chairmen Chairmen Chairmen of all the Standing Committees belonging to that House leaders of recognised parties / groups and such other members as may be nominated by the Presiding Officer .
The Committee is constituted to advise on such ad hoc matters concerning the affairs of the House and its members as do not appropriately fall within the purview of any other Parliamentary Committee and which may be specified from time to time .
The Library Committee is a Joint Committee of the two Houses consisting of six members of the Lok Sabha ( including the Deputy Speaker ) nominated by the Speaker and three members of the Rajya Sabha nominated by its Chairman .
The main function of this Committee is to help the members in the use of the library and its allied services सदस्यो i . e . reference research and documentation services .
It advises the Speaker on matters pertaining to the selection of books framing of library rules and its future planning etc .
A Joint Committee on Salaries and Allowances of Members of Parliament was constituted to frame rules under the Salaries and Allowances of Members of Parliament Act 1954 .
It consists of ten members from the Lok Sabha and five from the Rajya Sabha .
The functions of the Committee are to provide for the members of the two Houses for matters such as medical travel telephone and postal facilities to the Government of India in general consultation with the Government of India to regulate the payment of their daily and travelling allowances etc .

These rules are based on the Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business in both the Houses and have been gradually evolved from conventions and rulings given by the Presiding Officers from time to time .
The first Rules of conduct of the members for the House which they are to be obeyed when the meeting commences and the first rules of conduct of conduct of the House which should be taken up before the time of their meeting is fixed and भोजन .
Once the sitting of the House commences every member should enter and leave the Chamber with decorum and in such a manner as not to disturb the proceedings in the House .
While entering the Lok Sabha Chamber the members should bow to the Speaker at the time of their departure and when they leave their seats .
It is a respect to the House as a whole and not to a person on the Chair .
The Speaker represents the House to all outside bodies and authorities .
Regard for the authority of the Speaker as the symbol of the corporate personality of the House is the basic norm of parliamentary conduct .
While saying " A leading principle is that at one time only one member should speak or ask questions and the Chair is given the power to call upon the members to speak one by one .
When a member wants to speak he should rise in his place to attract the attention of the Presiding Officer .
A member having an economic interest where a matter has to be decided by the House in which a member has a pecuniary or direct interest the member is expected to declare that he shall take part in the action on the matter .

Apart from the rules of parliamentary etiquette which by members are to observe by them there are customs and conventions which are equally important in maintaining a proper standard of parliamentary life and maintaining the dignity of the House and its members .
Members of Parliament are therefore expected to retain a standard of conduct not only inside the House but outside the House .
The conduct of the members should not be contrary to the practice of सदस्यों or derogatory to the dignity of the House or against any standard which the Parliament expects its members .
The conduct of a member has not been fully explained in the broad sense of the words and in each case it is in the jurisdiction of the House whether the member of Parliament has been unfair or is not eligible .
Thus even if the facts in a particular case are not covered by a breach of privilege or contempt of the House the conduct of a member may be considered unfair and derogatory to the dignity of the House .
The House has the right to punish him for the conduct of its members whether it is within the House or outside the Parliament to exercise its right to conduct law .
There is also the power to punish the House for the disorderly conduct of its members other for all मान्यताएं whether committed within the House or outside the walls.
When a member violates any of the restrictions the Speaker may direct him to discontinue his speech or order the member to suspend business in the House .

Rigid or अथवा Constitutions may be called rigid or flexible on the basis of the difficult or simple procedure of the amending .
Federal Constitutions are usually classified as rigid because of their difficult amending procedure .
Our Constitution may be said to be a combination of rigid and flexible because certain Acts of the Constitution like Articles 2 4 and 4 and 169 can be amended as by simple majority in both the Houses of Parliament .
Only in the case of some of the provisions in addition to a special majority of the two Houses of Parliament an amendment would require the ratification of not less than half of the States Parties .
During the past 51 years there were as many as 83 amendments to our Constitution .

Equality before law and Equal protection of laws Article 14 of the Constitution enunciates the fundamental right of every person not to be denied within the territory of India equal protection of law and laws .
The protection provided by this article is not limited to citizens only but is applicable to all individuals .
It embodies the principle contained in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights that all are equal before the law and are entitled without any discrimination to equal protection .
In singular in the term equality before law means the same thing as the apparent word of law or the concept of law or of justice .
On the other hand in the term ' s uniform protection of the laws ' the word ' संरक्षण ' explains the statutory law and the provision made by it orders the State to ensure that all the safeguards are made without any distinction .
However since the Supreme Court has not seen any such distinction .
In fact Valmiki Chief Justice शास्त्री Sastri feels that the second rank is the result of the first position and is far more difficult to imagine the condition in which the rule of law is not subject to equality of the same protection as that of law .
( State of West Bengal v. Anwar AH Government AIR 1952 SC 75 ) .
Laws should be applied to all in a uniform case .
The Supreme Court has held that the varying needs of different classes of people often require different treatment .
According to him " , Lal v. Union of India AIR 1951 SC 41 .
If the classification is not reasonable and does not satisfy the two conditions referred to above the impugned legislation or executive action would plainly be arbitrary and the guarantee of equality under article 14 would be violation .
Therefore wherever it is in the State ' s action whether it is legislative or executive or by any authority under article 12 निरंकुशता निरंकुशता of निरंकुशता - LRB - article 14 - RRB - becomes active and निरंकुशता the action of the State .
Thus the new approach as enunciated by the Supreme Court has widened the scope for the operation of article 14 and no discrimination now required to be made against others .
कारपोरेशन v प्राजैक्ट and इक्विपमेंट Corporation ( 1984 ) 3 SCC 378 ) .

The use of the word is meaningful .
Any distinction based on one or more grounds and on other grounds or grounds would not have been affected by this article ( राज्य v. State of Bombay AIR 1953 b R . पी ) IPC and no distinctions based on residence .
Clause 2 of the article provides for particular enforcement of the prohibition .
The prohibition obviously covers the actions of both the State and the general public at large .
( A . N . Gopalan v. State of Madras AIR 1950 SC 27 ) .

Judicial Review 1 : The Constitution as it has developed in the United States has the right to the Supreme Court of the country to hear the final judgement in respect of the legality or illegality of legislative action in the country which is the law of the law .
Our Constitution very largely follows the U. S. practice in this regard .
Cases are often filed before the Supreme Court by a State Government or by an affected private individual or a party claiming that in enacting a particular law the concerned government exceeded its jurisdictional limit with regard to the division of powers under the Seventh Schedule .
While reviewing such enactment the Supreme Court will examine whether jurisdictional limits have been exceeded .
Incorporation of a Chapter on Fundamental Rights in the Constitution makes judicial review specially consistent .
And under this article ' the ' State ' has been defined as to make a judicial review of the Government of India and of the States ' all the state governments within the territory of Parliament and the Legislature and the Government of India .

Language of Legislatures Article 120 lays down the official language of Parliament .
Besides in it the Parliament has been asked to function in Hindi or English .
However the Presiding Officer of each House may ask any member who cannot adequately express himself in Hindi or English or allow him to address the House in his mother tongue .
It has therefore been arranged in both the Houses of Parliament to simultaneous interpretation of speeches from major regional languages into Hindi and English .
But in actual practice most of the time the entire business of each House is carried out in Hindi or English full facilities are given to the practice in Hindi to English and vice versa.
The corresponding language provision for State Legislatures is article 210 .
In the Legislature of the State the work shall be in the official language of the State or in Hindi or in English and the Presiding Officer of the House may move any member who cannot adequately express himself in any of these languages and may address the House in his mother tongue .

Parliament and State Legislatures The Constitution of India has established a federal system of government in the country as there is a distribution of legislative executive and financial powers between the Union and the States.
But it is extremely doubtful if Indian polity can be described as federal or federal .
The word संविधान is nowhere used in the text of the Constitution.
In fact the proposal to describe India as a फेडरशन was specifically turned down in the Constituent Assembly .
Article 1 of the Constitution described India as the Union of States .
There are many features of the Constitution and there are several provisions which very clearly and strongly हैं against it being a federal Constitution .
Unlike the United States of America the citizenship in India is one ; the flag is one ; the Constitution is one .
The Judiciary also is an integrated one and not divided between the Union and the States .
But in short there can be difference of opinion in regard to whether Indian polity is federal unitary or quasi - federal or it is a polity which is unitary in spirit but federal in structure .
The Union of India now consists of 25 states and seven Union Territories ( as specified in the First Schedule of the Constitution .
The Executive has the right to formulate the budget .
The Constitution provides for an annual statement of the estimated receipts and expenditure to be placed before the Parliament .
It has full freedom to suggest how revenue should be raised to meet the expenditure and thus the Government can take all the steps in public financial matters .
No taxes can be legally levied and no expenditure incurred from the public exchequer without specific parliamentary authorisation by law .

The modern concept of law is not to suggest that it is a set of rules of general application and so on .
Law is a process ; a long and complicated procedure which is linked to earlier social trends ; the first necessity and action to be followed by the सदनों of the सदनों as well as the सदनों of the सदनों and the laws concerned governments and other matters involved .
Thus it cannot be said that law - making does not constitute a body of persons or any part of the State ; the three organs of the State such as the Legislature the Executive the Legislature and the Legislature of the State play the role of legislation .

The procedure for constitutional amendment as spelled out in that article has certain distinctive features which clearly mark out the Parliament ' s constituent capacity from its ordinary role as a legislature .
First an amendment of the Constitution can be initiated only by raising a Bill in either House of Parliament ( as the initiative for amendment of the Constitution is reserved for Parliament alone .
Second in most cases the provisions of the Constitution can be amended by Parliament by a special majority namely a majority of not less than two - thirds of the members of each House present and voting .
Only in the case of the constitutional provisions of a limited category ( i . e . in the List of Seventh Schedule ) provisions in Parliament relating to the representation in the States ( article 352 ) etc. ( with a special majority ) Bill passed by Parliament .
Third the Constitution Amendment Bill having been duly passed and moved before the President has to give his assent to the Bill and the option shall not be returned to the House for a review of the Bill or for a review of the Bill .

The institution of the Speaker in India dates back to 1921 when the Central Legislative Assembly was first constituted under the Montague - Chelmsford reforms .
Sir Frederick फ्रेडरिक was appointed by the Governor - General as the first Speaker of the Assembly for a period of four years on 3rd February 1921 .
Shri Vithalbhai Patel was the first non - official to be elected the Speaker of the Assembly on 24 August 1925 .
He was re - elected on 20 January 1927 and remained in his office till 28 April 1930 at which he resigned his post .
Shri Patel had the distinction of being the first Indian and the first elected Speaker of the Central Legislature .
Shri G. V. Mavalankar was chosen as the first Speaker of the first Parliament constituted after the first general elections after independence .

The All - Parties Conference organised at Bombay on 19 May 1928 appointed a committee under the chairmanship of Motilal Nehru to formulate the principle of the Constitution of India .
The Report embodied not only the perspective of the contemporary nationalist ideology but also a framework of the draft constitution of India .
The draft of the Constitution of India was based on the principle of Dominion Status.
It laid down some fundamental rights and provided for a federal system with maximum autonomy granted to the units but residuary powers vested in the Central Government .
Almost twenty - one years later it was incorporated in the Constitution of free India adopted by the Constituent Assembly on 26 November 1949 .
The White Paper issued after the third Round Table Conference outlined the British government ' s proposal for constitutional reforms in India .
In June 1934 the Congress Working Committee declared that the only satisfactory alternative to the White Paper was the preparation of a Constitution by an elected Constituent Assembly on the basis of adult franchise .
This was the first occasion when a formal demand for the Constituent Assembly was introduced .
The Executive of the All India Congress Committee at its meeting held at Patna on 5 - 7 December 1934 adopted a proposal which ठुकरा the scheme of constitutional reform as recommended in the report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee ( 1933 - 34 ) agreed to this constitution .
Second the work load of the House is enormous.

Fourth since there is not much difference in the actually composition of the two Chambers in the Indian Parliament the सदन Rajya Sabha has become almost a parallel House .
Even if this were not so the Rajya Sabha could hardly be considered to be the traditional cooling or revising Chamber the सदन or the house of elders or experts guarding against hasty or faulty legislation .
Under the circumstances the Select Committees and the Joint Committees on Bills may inter alia perform the role of the traditional Second House .
Fifth in a party system that is ruled by a party like the दलीय in the Indian Parliament ( संसद ) some of the Committees perform functions that would otherwise belong to the opposition - they keep the Executive on its toes and prevent its becoming arbitrary .
The Secretariats thus function as independent entities under the supervision and control of the Chairman or the Speaker as the case may be .
In accordance with well - established conventions the orders issued by the Government of India to its ministries and departments not automatically applicable to the officers and staff of the Lok Sabha and the officers and staff of the Rajya Sabha Secretariat .
However if any modification or alteration etc. in a financial order is considered necessary the adoption order is issued after consulting the Ministry of Finance .
If the staff of the Legislature Secretariat were to depend upon the Home Ministry the Finance Ministry or any other department of the government for career prospects promotions pay scales etc. it is obvious that they could not be independent vis - a - vis the Executive .
Budget of the Two Houses of Parliament The position of independence is maintained also in respect of expenditure incurred in respect of salaries and allowances and amenities of both members and officers of the Parliament .
These expenses are met from the Consolidated Fund of India .
As in the case of other ministries of the Government of India separate demands for grants in respect of the Rajya Sabha and the Lok Sabha are also laid before both the Houses of Parliament .
The Parliament sanctions the expenditure through the Appropriation Act every year .
No cut motions or any discussion relating to the demands of the two Houses and their Secretariats is allowed in the House .
हाथ of hands to attract the attention of the Chair is not considered to be the normal parliamentary practice .
No member should speak unless he has caught the Chair ' s eye and the Chair is asked to speak.
The practice of exchanging arguments by members between themselves or of indulging in a soft of running commentary on another member ' s speech or of the minister ' s statement has been deprecated by the Speaker .
When a member is speaking in the House and any other member has during the course of the debate to raise a point of order or to offer a personal explanation with the permission of the Presiding Officer in the course of the debate he should resume his seat .
If a member wants to comment on any matter before the House or from any other member addressing a matter addressed to the House he / she needs to ask the question through the Speaker for the purpose of an explanation or any explanation .
The member should move from his appointed seat and rise .
However if a member is unable to do so for illness or disability he is allowed to speak while sitting by the Speaker .
A member should not address the members of the House while speaking but he should always address the Chair and make remarks to other members through the Chair.
The theory may appear to be a mere formality but it is practised efficiently so that the controversy does not take the form of dialogue between the members .
After examining the notice if the Speaker feels that there is no prima fade case of breach of privilege or the matter to be raised is not in order the Speaker may give his consent to the matter being made .

Under the citizenship provisions a single citizenship has been provided to all the people of India and no double citizenship of the Union and of the States as in the United States .
Thus संप्रभुता the Preamble provisions of our Constitution put an end to concepts of traditional संघवाद संप्रभुता divided sovereignty autonomy of States etc .
Moreover the founding fathers of the राज्यों sought to clarify for all times that Sovereignty in our scheme of things vests in the people themselves and that all the organs and functionaries of the Union and the States drew their powers from the people of India .

PART II नागरिकता 5 - 11 Citizenship constitutes the indispensable foundational principle of democratic polity .
Broadly the amended section 3 of the principal Act provided that citizenship by birth could be acquired by a person only if either of his parents was a citizen of India at the time of birth .
Besides the Act made provisions for acquisition of Indian citizenship by birth , origin , registration . . or through incorporation of the territory .
Likewise it provided for termination of citizenship by way of renunciation voluntary acquisition of citizenship of another country or through compulsory deprivation by the Government of India from citizenship on certain grounds .
The Act also made specific provisions regarding Commonwealth Citizenship .
Any person born outside India after 26 January 1950 subject to certain requirements will be a citizen of India ; if his father was a citizen of India at the time of his birth .
It is important to remember in regard to the citizenship provisions in the Constitution and the law that the founding fathers decided to provide for a single Indian citizenship with a view to building an integrated Indian nation and a united fraternity .
All citizens irrespective of their birth in any State have the same rights and duties all over the country without distinction .
PART III - III अधिकार 12 - 35 When the Constituent Assembly took over the task of framing the Constitution the first aim was to create a right discrimination .
A comprehensive charter of rights was soon evolved through various stages in the Assembly and its Committees .
Dr .
Coming closely on the heels of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights India ' s Constitution मानव the contemporary democratic and humanitarian temper and constitutional practice in other countries of the world .
It was a testimony to how eager the founding fathers were to incorporate and implement the fundamental principles enunciated in the Universal Declaration .
Also incorporation of a charter of fundamental rights in our Constitution became necessary in view of the special problem of minorities and the need to assure them of the fullest protection of their rights .
The values of freedom and equality befitting the dignity of man are very asserted in the Preamble .
These fundamental rights substantially cover all the traditional civil and political rights enumerated in articles 2 to 21 of the Universal Declaration .
Protection of equality before law and common protection of all laws ( article 14 ) in respect of conviction for offences ( article 20 ) protection of life and personal liberty ( article 21 ) protection of arrest and detention of all persons ( article 22 ) .
But there are rights which can be claimed only by citizens : such as religion based on profession caste creed sex or place of birth ( articles 15 ) नागरिकों of opportunity ( articles 16 ) नागरिकों of public employment and speeches articles 16 ) .
Originally article 19 ( f ) and article 31 contained the right of the property to acquire hold and dispose of the property that is to be acquired by the authority of the State ' s law for the public purpose .
But when the Constitution ( 44th Amendment ) Act 1978 1978 has omitted sub - clause ( f ) of Article 19 ( f ) and all Article 31 ( f ) the right to property has not been a fundamental right since .
Articles द्वारा and द्वारा inserted by the First Constitutional Amendment and article की inserted by the Twenty - fifth Amendment sought to provide for the acquisition of estates in the Ninth Schedule to the laws provided for protection of the estates Acts and regulations specified by the Directive Principles .
Articles 33 - 35 enable the Parliament to बलों on the defence forces by part 3 of the Constitution .
It is true that the fundamental human rights enshrined in the Constitution of India are hedged परिसीमाओं many limitations and restrictions .
The fundamental rights which the individual enjoys are in the nature of limitations or restrictions on the actions of the state .
( State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose AIR 1954 SC 92 ) .

Speaking in the Constituent Assembly Dr .

The Directive Principles are an effective part of the Constitution and are an important part of this vision for the Constitution seeks to achieve the ideals of a democratic welfare state in the Preamble and to the realization of the social and economic revolution that the founding fathers .
The Preamble the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles together .
Both the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles are the soul of the Constitution .
It is now clear that there is no essential dichotomy between Rights and Duties or between the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles .
They are complement and supplement each other .

Functions of Parliament Traditionally the main function of the Legislature is to make laws .
Under article 245 - 246 Parliament can make laws for the whole or any part of India within its area of competence as defined and delimited under the distribution of legislative powers between the Union and the States vide the Seventh Schedule .
Only the Parliament can legislate in respect of the Union List .
Both the Union and the States have concurrent power to legislate in respect of entries in the concurrent proceedings .
If there is a conflict between the Union and the State laws the former prevails ( article 254 ) .
The residuary powers also vest in the Parliament ( Article शक्तियां of the Union List and entry ( 97 ) .
In a number of articles the Parliament has been given authority to make laws in various matters dealing with such powers as may be provided by Parliament by law otherwise provided by Parliament " Parliament may not by Parliament by law ' and so on .
No grounds arguments proofs or justification are required .
Parliamentary control over public finance : power to levy or modify taxes and voting of supplies and grants is the most important checks against the Executive assuming arbitrary powers .
No taxes can be legally levied and no expenditure incurred from the public exchequer without specific parliamentary authorization by law ( articles 114 - 116 and 265 ) .
Administrative accountability is ensured through legislation through parliamentary devices like , , questions discussions on various motions संसद scrutiny through the संसद Committee and the minister who actually represents the Parliament and controls his department on behalf of Parliament .

The judge so appointed is duty bound to give priority to the Supreme Court duties .

Power and jurisdiction of the Supreme Court :
The President may seek the opinion of the Supreme Court on any question of law or fact of public importance on which he thinks it expedient to obtain such an opinion .
After such reference from the President the Supreme Court will report its opinion on the President after such hearing as it deems fit .
The President is free to recognise it or not .
The President may also seek the assistance of the Supreme Court through a similar reference on any treaty agreement covenant engagement प्रसंविदा engagement प्रसंविदा engagement प्रसंविदा or other similar instrument which had been entered into or executed before the commencement of this Constitution and thereafter the appeal lies with the Supreme Court .
Under article 138 the Supreme Court shall have such further jurisdiction and powers with respect to any of the matters in the Union List as Parliament may by law .
This enlarges the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court and provides it with very special jurisdiction to hear cases of most urgent nature directly and in its original jurisdiction for speedy disposal .
The due process of law gives wide scope to the Supreme Court to grant protection to the rights of its citizens .
It can declare laws violative of these rights void not only on substantive grounds of being unlawful but also on procedural grounds of being inappropriate .
It is not expected to go into the question of its reasonableness suitability or policy implications.
The Supreme Court pronounces its judgement on a specific case through a specific petition .
He does not give opinion or advice on general directions .
There should be an aggrieved person who petitions the Court to challenge the constitutionality of the statute which has adversely affected his rights .
He has to show that he has suffered from immediate injury as a result of the enforcement of the statute and that the injury complained of is शिकायत .
This decision has left the न्यायिक individual or NGOs to seek judicial relief in the interest of the public .
The law declared to be binding by Article 141 the law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts within the territory of India .
Therefore if the Supreme Court declares a law as opposed to the Constitution even if it is a legislative competence or a violation of fundamental rights it will be binding on all courts in the territory of India .
Independence of the कार्यपालिका In a representative democracy administration of justice assumes special significance in view of the rights of individuals which need protection against executive or legislative interference .
An independent and supreme judiciary is an essential requisite of a federal polity wherein there is a constitutional division of powers between the federal government and governments of the constituent units and a functional division of powers between the executive राज्य legislature and the judiciary .
Also an independent and impartial judiciary is an essential requisite for ensuring human rights and protecting democracy .
Only an independent judiciary can act effectively as the guardian of the rights of the individual and the Constitution .
The Constitution provides for a High Court for each state .
Parliament may however establish by law a common High Court for two or more States or for two or more States and a Union territory ( articles न्यायालय and न्यायालय ) .
A higher court issues any inferior court or tribunal and it is intended to prohibit it from exceeding its jurisdiction .
Besides writs the High Courts under Article 226 can also issue other directions and orders in the interest of justice ( T. C . 440 v. न्यायालय AIR 1954 SC 440 ) .

The Government of India Act 1935 1935 proposed to set up a federal polity in India with a central government and the Provinces deriving their jurisdiction and powers from the Crown .
Since a limited responsible government was established only at the provincial level the nationalists naturally asked for more powers for provincial legislatures .
When the Constituent Assembly met in 1946 and early 1947 the idea was to have a federation with a Centre having limited powers .
Before the Union Constitution Committee could transact any worthwhile business the Mountbatten Plan of 3 June 1947 was declared .
All hopes of preserving the unity of the nation vanished and the partition of the country on communal lines became a firm decision .
The Union Constitution Committee and the Provincial Constitution Committee decided at a joint meeting on 5 June that in view of the 3 June announcement the limitations imposed by the Cabinet Mission ' s plan on the form of the constitution had disappeared .
When Partition became a reality there was no need to appease the Muslim League and restrict the powers of the Union Government .

Articles 256 to 265 seek to regulate administrative relations between the Union and the States .
It is common in federal systems that the administrative relations between the Union and the States are fraught with difficulties.
The Constitution of India seeks to achieve a smooth working relationship between the two planes .
It provides that the executive powers of the State Government are to be exercised in such a way as to ensure compliance with the laws made by Parliament .
The Union Executive is also empowered to give such directions to the States which appear to the Government of India to be necessary for this purpose .
Under article 258 the President may with the consent of a State Government entrust to that Government or its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the Union Executive power is extended .

The भारतीय Report . 1918 - 22 is known as the Report on Indian Constitutional Reforms - or भारतीय Report .

The provisions of the 1919 Act and the rules framed there were many important changes in the then Indian constitutional system .
The seat of the Central Legislative Council was replaced by a bicameral legislature consisting of a Council of State ( Upper House ) and the Legislative Assembly ( Lower House ) .
There is no limitation on the power of amendment that is there is no provision in the Constitution which cannot be amended .
The fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution ( Part 3 ) are subject to the Parliamentary power of the Constitution ( भाग ) .
In the गोलकनाथ case the Supreme Court has reversed its earlier decisions by a majority of 6 - 7 and held that the Constitution has not passed any amendment of the Constitution article 368 without any amendment to the Constitution or the Parliament to amend it .
In 1973 in the गोलकनाथ Bharti v. State of Kerala ( AIR 1973 SC गोलकनाथ ) the Supreme Court reviewed the verdict of the Golak Nath case .
Ten of the 13 judges held that Art. 368 itself contained the power to amend the Constitution and the law of Article 13 ( 2 ) did not absorb the constitutional amendment under Art. 368 .
The law declared in Golak Nath case was accordingly उलट .
Regarding the question whether the power of amendment under Art. 368 was arbitrary and infinite ; seven judges decided by a majority in the opinion that the amending power was vested in the Constitution - which was necessary under the meaning of the Constitution .
But what the infrastructure is but it was not made clear by the majority and the question remains controversial .
In the शक्तियों case after this decision the Constitution ( संसद Amendment ) Act 1976 1976 added 4 and 5 to Article 368 and the limitations of the powers of amendments to Parliament were reduced .

On 4 November 1948 while introducing the draft of the Constitution in the assembly and recommending for the parliamentary system the Chairman of the Drafting Committee said that " The Draft Constitution " has preferred more responsibility to recommending an शासन system of Governance .
Though some of the sounds were heard against the idea of a parliamentary system the draft committee moved by a large majority in its proposals and the coming into force on January 26 1950 with the coming into force of the Constitution of Free India .
The three राजनीतिक representative राजनीतिक parliamentary and democracy? are the cardinal features of our political system .
At the beginning of the first session after every general election to the Lok Sabha and at the commencement of the first session of each year the President addresses both Houses of Parliament assembled together and the causes of the Parliament to invite a meeting of the Houses .
Further he may address either House of Parliament or both Houses assembled together and for this purpose require the attendance of members .
He has the power to send सदन or any other message to any House in respect of a Bill which is then pending in Parliament the House shall readily consider the subject which may be required to be considered by the House at such time .
Some Bills may be introduced only after the recommendation of the President has been examined or proceeded further .
According to the Constitution there are certain other functions about Parliament which are expected to be discharged by the President .
He appointed the Speaker and the Executive Chairman of the Council of States whenever necessary .
It is for him a joint sitting of the two Houses in case of disagreement between the two Houses on a Bill .
Every year the budget of the Government . referred to as the Annual Financial Statement in the Constitution of India and the Comptroller and Auditor - General of India The Union Public Service Commission . is special report to the Members of Parliament and some other backward classes .
If he is of the opinion that the Anglo - Indian community does not have adequate representation in the Lok Sabha he may nominate not more than two members for the House .
Other ministers are appointed by the President on the advice of the Prime Minister .
It may be added that the President has not the opportunity of exercising a private desire to appoint the Prime Minister .
However if a situation arises that no party has a clear majority in the Lok Sabha the President may exercise his power to choose a leader who in his opinion is likely to command the support of the majority in the House .
The Prime Minister usually is a member of the Lok Sabha but the Ministers are drawn to both Houses of Parliament .
A person who is not a member of either House of Parliament has to vacate the office after six months unless in the meanwhile he manages to get himself elected to either of the two Houses .
At the same time every minister holds office during the pleasure of the President and shall be liable to dismissal by him .
But since the President does so only on the advice of the prime minister this power actually rests with the prime minister .
The relationship between the Executive and the Legislature is always one and there is no scope for any opposition or division .
The power of the two is not visualised as competing centres but as inseparable partners or या in the business of the two .
The Council of Ministers may in a sense be described as the grand executive committee of the Parliament charged with the responsibility of governance on behalf of the parent body .
In other words the executive is not a separate or outside body .
There is however a clear distinction between the functions of the Executive and the functions of the Parliament .
The function of Parliament is to make laws give advice on how to criticise and ventilate public grievances .
The Executive is to govern albeit on behalf of the Parliament .
In the words of the first Secretary of the Indian Parliament :
The Parliament must not at any time participate in the responsibilities of the government because once the Parliament has begun to do so the responsibilities of the Parliament and the Executive become vague and cannot exercise its full power of criticism .
Article 13 of the Constitution clearly prohibits the making of any law by Parliament the State Legislature or by any other authority which would be inconsistent with or in derogation of any of the fundamental rights contained in Part III of the Constitution .
Article 32 226 confer power on the Supreme Court and the High Courts respectively for the enforcement of these rights .
The हनन is contrary to the provisions of the Constitution or हनन to any one in fundamental rights .
It is sometimes assumed and often said that just as it is for the Legislature to make laws and for the Executive to execute them it is for the Courts to interpret the Constitution and the laws .
It is very misleading and patently wrong .
The territory of the Union is divided among the States .
A law made by a State can be applicable only in the territory of that State .
The Union Parliament can make laws for the whole or any part of the territory of India .
Parliament also enjoys the power of extra - territorial legislation i . e . any law made by it will be applicable not only to the people and property within the territory of India but also to Indian citizens living abroad .
The States do not have the power to legislate .
The Constitution provides for a three - fold distribution of legislative power between the Union and the States .
List I or the Union List contains 97 subjects over which the Parliament can make laws .
List II or the State List includes 66 entries over which State Legislatures can make laws only .
List III or the Concurrent List contains 47 items on which both the Parliament and the State Legislatures can make laws .
While in their own respective spheres as allotted by the Constitution the Central Parliament and the State Legislatures enjoy complete autonomy the scheme of distribution of powers emphasises the general predominance of the Parliament in the legislative field .
The Parliament also has the power to legislate for implementing the decisions made by a treaty agreement or convention with a country or on any matter at an international conference organisation or other body even if the subject falls in the State List .
The Parliament may legislate even on any matter in the State List .
If two or more State Legislatures consider it desirable that any of the matters within their exclusive legislative competence should be regulated by parliamentary legislation and pass resolutions to that effect the Parliament can undertake the necessary legislation .
However the legislation so passed is governed by those States who have moved for it and others who passed their resolutions in that direction .
Some of the entries in the Union List are also empowered by the Parliament to lead the Parliament to its own area and subject matter within the territory of the state by establishing requisite by law .
Parliament has the power to separate the territory of any State or by uniting two or more States .
( c ) can alter the boundaries of any state ; and ( d ) in the name of any state .
These changes are not the way of the amendment of the Constitution but such amendments as can be made by Parliament by passing a Bill on the recommendation of the President .
Such a Bill is required to be referred to the legislatures of the States concerned for expressing their views thereon within the time stipulated for this purpose .
However the passing of the Bill to the Legislatures does not lose the power to change as it thinks fit .

The operative reality of politics today is that the real power resides in the Prime Minister and his or her cabinet and not in Parliament .
The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority in the Lok Sabha and also the head of the government .
He may consult two or three colleagues and go ahead.
It is ultimately the prime minister who is responsible to the Parliament and the nation for the policies of the government . "
Administration is run by the permanent civil services .
The Parliament does not interfere with day - to - day administration nor does it control the administration .
Often the Press struggles hard to unearth the administrative lapses scandals and shortcomings gives expression to public grievances and difficulties and reports on how policies are being carried out .
Much of the information obtained from the daily newspapers for parliamentary discussions is an important instrument on which the members depend .
Simultaneously the संसद Press keeps the people informed of what is happening in Parliament .
This two - way traffic enables the Press to maintain an important and strong link between the public and the Parliament .
Considering the space that is devoted to these matters and the volume of information that is given the Press in our country fulfils a great need felt alike by the members of Parliament and the public .
Even though so much information from such a variety of sources is available to Parliament it is not enough.
The information supplied by the official government sources is efficiently collected and processed but it may sometimes consciously or unconsciously get पक्षपातपूर्ण or biased and may always be strictly complete factual and objective .
Information from other sources like the mass media political parties interest groups or लॉबी even those standing by the लॉबी would be even less so.
The government is sensitive to the opinion of the Parliament ; in most cases he has already known ; in some cases he may feel that he cannot change his commitments and obligations and political ideology .
However during discussions members have full freedom to criticise and suggest how they work in the future or how a particular measure of action may be carried out .
The discussions have made the people ' s views on the administrative machinery and if this is not the administration is unaware of the sentiments of the people .
Parliamentary debates serve to remind the administration of its duties and obligations .
Parliamentary debates effect the administrative thinking and action in a variety of ways and the subtle influence which cannot be measured in terms of any visible units pervades through the upper and lower strata of administration .
While the administrators have complete freedom to implement their policies in the best manner possible by the Parliament they are nevertheless haunted and guided by the various viewpoints expressed in the House .
And this may be called the Advisory Role of Parliament .
Conflict is natural to be a conflict between one ' s life and struggle for power by various contending forces .
Parliamentary democracy is considered to be a better and more civilized system of government inasmuch as under it debate and discussion on the legislative floor take the place of physical strife on the streets or on the battle fields of the street .
This is especially so when charges are made against a person who has no opportunity of coming before the House and explaining his position .
Before being admitted to ascertain the factual basis of such questions the Ministry / Department may be referred to the concerned Ministries / Departments .
Members are also sometimes asked to post material in support of the allegations made in the question .
Besides if the subject of a question is pending for judgement before a court of law or any other tribunal or body constituted under law or before a Parliamentary Committee it is not permitted to be questioned .
It may be noted that questions should not relate to any matter which is not fundamentally related to the Government of India .
Questions that contain arguments findings or व्यक्ति statements or refer to one ' s character or conduct not in his official or public capacity but questions which have been asked for information instead of asking for information .
The questions are put in starred or अतारांकित categories according to the conditions provided in the rules .

The Mission rejected the demand for the creation of a separate sovereign state as it believed that there would be a large number of non - Muslim population in Pakistan and the vast majority of Muslims would be left outside Pakistan .
The Cabinet Mission also rejected the Congress scheme of a loose federation as involving constitutional disadvantages and anomalies .
It recommended a three - tier structure consisting of the organisation of the Union of India at the top groups of Provinces in the centre and the States at the bottom .
The Cabinet Mission recommended that the Constitution should be based on the constitution : one India federation consisting of the British Indian states and which deals with the following subjects : Defence and Communication Defence and विदेश .
An executive and legislative body of the Union should consist of representatives of British India and the princely states .
If there is a question raising a major communal issue in the Legislature it should be disposed of by a majority of the representatives present and voting of each of the two principal communities and a majority of all the members present and voting.
All subjects and rights other than those entrusted to the Union shall vest .
There should be a provision in the memorandum of the Union and the groups for which a province can re - emerge from the majority of its Legislative Assembly after an initial period of 10 years and after that of the Constitution for a period of ten years .

Though the purpose of asking questions by definition is to get information in actual practice most of the , are to provide information in practice .

From this point of view parliamentary questions are certainly helpful to the Executive for they put into focus areas of vital concern to the public .

It was therefore considered that some procedure might be devised whereby members might have an opportunity of bringing urgent matters to the attention of the government .
In the modern parliamentary procedure the idea of introducing Calling Attention Notices in the Rules of Procedure is purely an Indian innovation.
fill in
Sometimes it gives opportunity to members to criticise the government directly or indirectly and to bring to the surface the failure or inadequate action of the government in an important matter .
A member with the previous permission of the Speaker / Chairman may draw the attention of a minister to any matter of urgent public importance and request him to make a statement on that matter .
The minister may make a short statement or ask for a reply at a later date .
The members' chief source for होते the Calling Attention Notices is the daily newspapers .
Sometimes they may be based on the private information of a member or on the correspondence between him and his constituents .
Notices of Calling Attention have to be given by members in writing by 10. 00 .
A member cannot give two or more notices for any meeting .
Notices on the same subject may be given by more than one member but names of not more than five members are shown in the List of Business.
The Speaker goes through the notices and selects one of them for a statement by the concerned minister at the sitting of the House on the following day .
In some cases the Speaker may select two notices for a meeting .
However if the Speaker is of the opinion that the matter is so urgent that a statement should be made on the same day he may in his discretion allow विवेकाधिकार to go on the same day as his notice has been given .
The idea behind admitting Calling Attention Notices a day or so in advance is that it would give sufficient time to the minister concerned to gather facts about the matter raised and prepare a statement from time to time .
No more than two notices can be taken up at a meeting to give the attention of the ministers .
There is no debate on such a statement but every member in whose name the matter is listed is permitted to ask a question of है .
The main purpose of calling attention is therefore to seek an authoritative statement from a minister on a matter of urgent nature .
This process does not involve any censure against the government as there is no regular discussion and voting.
Among the matters to which the Ministers have been asked to make a statement are : there are trouble in any part of India ; Border dispute झगडे ; stay of the railway विमानों ; public authorities in which serious allegations were made by the Courts .
While raising the issue the member is not permitted to deviate from the approved text of his statement .
The minister concerned writes to the member directly with regard to matters raised under Rule 377 informing him of the government views and the action taken in the matter .
It may be noted that matters so raised are not included in the List of Business .
Prior to the fourth Lok Sabha use of Rule 377 for raising matters in the House was somewhat restricted before the fourth session but afterwards the more liberal approach has been adopted to meet various matters of public importance particularly as early as possible .
It has been observed that the members are increasingly taking recourse to this rule and the process has become very popular .
While during the Fourth Lok Sabha only 36 matters were allowed to be raised under Rule 377 during the Fifth Sixth Seventh and Eighth Lok Sabhas such matters numbered 184 . में . and सभा respectively.

Joint - sitting of the two सदनों In case of a deadlock due to disagreement सदनों the two Houses on a Bill an extraordinary situation arises which is resolved by both the Houses sitting together .
The President is empowered under the Constitution to revert to the Bill if the Bill has not lapsed due to the dissolution of the Lok Sabha both the Houses are invited to a joint - sitting for the purpose of joint consultation and voting .
Such a joint - sitting is presided over by the Speaker and is assisted by the Secretary - General . Lok Sabha .
The procedure rules of the Lok Sabha are applicable to the joint - sitting .
Only such amendments can be proposed at the joint - sitting which have become necessary due to the delay in passing the Bill .
The decisions at such sittings are taken by the majority of the total number of members of both the Houses present and voting.
So far only two bills the Dowry Prohibition Bill दहेज and the Banking Service Commission ( Repeal ) Bill has been passed at joint - sitting .
( 5 ) The President ' s assent to Bills when a Bill is passed by both the Houses either at a separate or joint - sitting it is presented to the President for his assent .
If the President . his assent there is an end to the Bill .
The Rajya Sabha cannot reject a Money Bill nor can it amend it by virtue of its own power to amend any such Bill .
If any of the recommendations made by the Rajya Sabha are accepted by the Lok Sabha the Money Bill is deemed to have been passed by both the Houses with the recommendations accepted by the Lok Sabha and accepted by the Lok Sabha .
If the Lok Sabha does not accept any of the recommendations made by the Rajya Sabha the Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both the Houses in the form passed by the Lok Sabha before the amendments recommended by the Rajya Sabha .
Besides if any passed and a Money Bill passed for recommendation of the Rajya Sabha is not returned to the Lok Sabha within the said period of 14 days it shall be deemed to have been passed by both the Houses after the expiration of 14 days .
There is no question of disagreement between the two Houses with regard to Money Bills as in the case of an ordinary Bill because it enjoys as much power as in the case of the Lok Sabha as in the case of ordinary Bills .
Hence there is no provision of a joint - sitting in the case of a Money Bill .
financial
Generally speaking a Financial Bill means a Bill which relates to revenue or expenditure .
But being not a Money Bill the सभा Rajya Sabha is fully empowered to reject or amend it as it does in the case of an ordinary Bill .
Also there can be no amendment in either of the two Houses without the recommendation of the President ; the resolution is passed on to both the Houses except in the case of a simple bill and removal of taxes between the two Houses .
The provision of a joint - sitting does not apply to the case of a Money Bill .
The Finance Bill of class B which inter alia contains one or more proposals for expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India which does not include any matter mentioned in Article 110 ( c ) is considered a General Bill or for the same reasons .
It does not require the recommendation of the President for its presentation .
However the recommendation of the President is essential for its consideration by either House .
In other words . is not a condition that the President may recommend it before he has moved as in the case of a Money Bill and a Finance Bill but in this case the President cannot recommend the Bill unless such .
In all other respects the procedure of a Bill involving the provision of a joint - sitting is the same as that of an ordinary Bill in case of disagreement between the two Houses .
The procedure for amendment of the Constitution ( संविधान ) was laid down in Art. 368 .
The Constitution does not provide for a separate constituent body ; the power to amend the Constitution is vested in Parliament .
A Bill to amend the Constitution can be introduced in either of the two Houses of Parliament .
Such a Bill may be brought by the Government or by a private member .
Generally Constitution ( Amendment ) Bills brought forward by Ministers are introduced in the Lok Sabha .
Apart from being subject to the ordinary rules governing Bills for a non - government member it is also necessary to examine and recommend the Committee on Private Members' Bills and Resolutions to introduce the Bill in the House .
But it is not bound by the views so gained .
By convention a motion for leave to introduce a Private Member ' bill is not opposed .
If the motion for introduction is opposed on the ground that it is outside the legislative competence of the House the Chair may permit full discussion thereon and thereafter put the motion for the decision of the House by vote of the House.
Ordinarily a member can introduce four Bills in a session .
After a Bill is introduced in the Lok Sabha and before it is taken up for consideration in the House the Committee on Private Members' Bills and Resolutions में the nature of the Bill . and b में them into two categories .
In Lok Sabha the relative precedence of Bills in a particular category is determined by लोक .
The Bills are included in the List of Business in the order of priority determined by the कार्य .
In a parliamentary system the Legislature has to lay down the policies of the Government ; it is the business of law - making and the monitoring of the administration .
But the enormous range and complexity of legislation and administrative functions of a modern State make it almost impossible for the Legislature to adequately scrutinise legislative proposals and oversee administrative action .
While the government has vast and highly sophisticated administrative machinery and organisation manned by experts specialists and seasoned civil servants at its' disposal to undertake its complex tasks the Legislature finds itself severely handicapped in this regard.
Through parliamentary devices like questions and debates it can directly monitor the administration .
In order to make parliamentary surveillance more effective and meaningful the Parliament needs an agency of its own in which the whole House is confident .
This among other things inter alia seeks to be sought by the Parliament through its Committees composed of a few of its members in which India has this position especially .
The review of administrative action and the examination of numerous and complicated legislative proposals and subordinate legislation require expertise and close scrutiny that are not possible in the Lok Sabha consisting as it does of 545 members .
Ad hoc Committees Such Committees may be broadly put into two categories : ( a ) Select or Joint Committees on Bills which may consider and report on particular Bills .
These Committees differ from other ad hoc Committees to the effect that the Bills are referred to and the procedure followed by them is laid down by the Speaker in the directives of the respective Houses and when the decisions are made by the Chairman .

Position of the Estimates Committee
In this case a distinction has been made between ' policy ' and all other policies laid down by Parliament by means of any statute ' or by specific resolutions ' by Parliament ' and not so laid down ' .
In the latter case the Parliamentary Committee may openly examine any matter which may have been settled as a policy by the government in the discharge of its executive functions .
The Committee may examine the working of the policy ; and not the policy as approved by the Parliament .
Thus where it is found that the intended consequences of a particular policy are not coming out and is being wasted there is a duty of the Estimates Committee to bring the shortcomings into the light and it is brought into consideration by the Parliament .
It consists of 22 members ( 15 from Lok Sabha and 7 from the Rajya Sabha ) .
In accordance with the practice prevailing since 1967 a member of the Opposition is appointed as the Chairman of the Committee .
The Estimates Committee deals with estimates of public expenditure ; and Public Accounts Committee mainly deals with the accounts receivable lent by the House for the expense of the Government of India with the objective of which it is authorised to ascertain by the Parliament .
If during any financial year additional expenditure has been incurred by the House for the purpose of any service for the purpose of any service the Committee examines the conditions under which such additional expenses are incurred and is justified by it .
Such excesses are required to be brought before the House by the government for व्यय .
It might also record its opinion in the form of disapproval or pass निरनुमोदन against the extravagance or lack of proper control by the ministry / department concerned .
The Committee draws its subjects for examination from the audit reports of the Comptroller and Auditor - General of India relating to the accounts of the Union which are laid before each House of Parliament .
The Comptroller and Auditor - General of India who participates in the meetings of the Committee assist the Committee.
The Committee has two broad सीमाएं one that it is not concerned with the question of policy and the other that its findings are ex post के .
In other words the Committee can point out irregularities only after they have taken place and the damage has been reached .
However the investigations of the अधिकारी Committee are taken very seriously by the authorities .
The very fact of the existence of such a Committee has a deterrent effect on a possible administrative waste and waste .
The recommendations of the Committee have led to administrative lapses in policy implementation हैं significant improvements in the financial system .
A policy of planned economic development for our country in the field of public enterprises has necessitated setting up of numerous industrial undertakings industrial undertakings commercial etc. which are controlled and managed by the Government of India .
Thus a number of corporations and government companies धनराशियां commonly called " public धनराशियां have come into existence involving large sums of money .
Since the moneys invested in them are appropriated from the Consolidated Fund of India it becomes the responsibility of the Lok Sabha to have adequate control over their functions .
For this purpose a Committee on Public Undertakings consisting of 22 Members elected from the Lok Sabha and 7 from the Rajya Sabha has been constituted by Parliament .
The Chairman of the Committee is appointed by the Speaker from among the members of the Committee drawn from the Lok Sabha .
The functions of the Committee are to examine the reports of the government undertakings specified in the Rules and reports of the accounts and of the Comptroller and Auditor - General if any whether the business practices are to be carried out in accordance with the reasonable business principles of government undertakings .

Parliamentary Museum and Archives India has always accorded maximum importance to parliamentary institutions.
Of late . In this region efforts are being made to harness all the necessary resources for collecting and preserving for the present and future generations .
A beginning was made in 1976 when the Lok Sabha Secretariat set up a Parliamentary Archives of संसदीय and Films to preserve a comprehensive complete and up - to - date pictorial record of the history of the institution of Parliament its activities and personalities.
The proposal for setting up a Parliamentary Museum and Archives was approved by the General Purposes Committee of the Lok Sabha on 1 August 1984 .
The basic purpose of the Parliamentary Museum and Archives is to protect the political and political institutions from the present age of the Constitution and Parliament and all the precious records of the past राजनीतिक historical documents and objects from changes in past to time and for future generations .
At the current stage of its growth it is concentrating on acquisition and building of comprehensive collections proper preservation of all its holdings and display of selected material .
In due course it proposes to undertake other tasks devoted to dissemination of information on parliamentary institutions and the projection of a proper image of Parliament by stimulating interest in its growth activities and its achievements .

A . R . ब्लेकशीड who tried to fix the perception and parameters of secularism ' in the West were unable to arrive at any fully viable and acceptable definition of the term .
Secular State must have nothing to do with religious affairs : except when their management involves crime fraud or becomes a threat to unity and integrity of the state .
On the contrary are the शासन or the शासन of one ' s autocratic rule .
The fundamental signs of democracy are that the sovereignty vests in the people ; the creed of religion the creed of religion the diversity of the caste स्त्री the gender caste group the system of administration without distinction of gender distinction of education or of professional background .
In a democracy the people are supposed to be their own masters .
They have an inalienable right to rule themselves or to be ruled in the way they like and by the people they choose .
Democracy also recognises the fact that from time immemorial human beings have been fighting with each other for power or authority .
Democracy tries to substitute a more civilised manner of fighting.
It presents the methods of discussion and persuasion in place of the armed conflict .
In ancient Indian Village Republics and the Greek City States all the citizens assembled together and decided issues of governance .
From the British Commonwealth it became the Commonwealth of Nations .
The Commonwealth specifically recognised India ' s status as a sovereign independent Republic .
It has therefore no bearing on the rich democratic or republican nature of the State .
Social and economic democracy : Democracy in a purely political sense means that every citizen has the right to freely vote in elections at a time .
In all democratic elections the principle of " one man . a man of faith " has come into force because of the recognition of the fact that all men are equal rights whether highly educated or illiterate businessmen or illiterate businessmen are श्रमिक .
For our founding fathers however democracy did not mean merely political democracy or the people ' s right to periodically vote to elect their representatives .
Without social and economic democracy political democracy had no meaning in a poor country like India .
Dr .
Ambedkar social and economic democracy was the real aim and ultimate goal .
He said that parliamentary democracy was meaningless unless it was geared to achieving the real goal of economic democracy .
Jawaharlal Nehru had observed later that Democracy of his conception was only a means to an end .
The objective is to provide an excellent life for every person that needs a certain measure of essential economic needs .
Only in the measure that democracy succeeds in solving the economic problems does it succeed even in the political field .
If the economic problems are not solved then the political structure tends to weaken and crack .
It is made clear by the words of the Preamble that all the citizens of the Republic were given " social न्याय economic and political justice " .
Justice means a harmony between the interests of individuals व्यक्तियों groups and between the individuals and groups on the one hand and the interests of the community on the other .
What is most important is that the Preamble places Justice higher than the principles of freedom equality and fraternity .
The concept of justice is indeed very wide .
It is not confined to the narrow legal justice as administered by courts .
Social justice implies that all citizens are treated equally and their status in society is not in any way due to the status of all men women ' s caste laws ' s caste laws status title etc.
Article 15 prohibits discrimination or disability in the matter of access to public places .
The humane conditions of work ; maternity relief leisure promoting economic interests among the backward classes the minimum wage the ban on forced labour and so on are the aims of social justice .
In economic justice there is a need to treat the rich and the poor and try to bridge the gap between them .
In pursuance of the objective of economic justice पुरुषों ( article 39 ) guides the state of शोषण to ensure that adequate means of livelihood to all citizens are not provided by those who are not dependent on them ; they are protected from the welfare of society ; and by the ; they are provided by the common law ; they are provided by the ; they are not by the ; they are provided by the welfare of the welfare of the welfare of men ; they are provided ; they are denied equality of the welfare of
In fact various other passages in Part IV of the Constitution ( articles 36 to 51 ) are also directed towards securing a new social and economic order imbued with justice .
The concept embodied in our Preamble is only that of equality of status and opportunity .
legal सामाजिक social , political and economic aspects .
All citizens are equal before law and enjoy equal protection of the laws of the country .
All citizens are equally entitled to enjoy the political rights to vote and participate in the process of governance without any discrimination .
In the economic field equality means a वेतन of ability and a pay for one ' s labour .
Moreover the शोषण will not exploit one person or one class other persons or classes .
The concept of equality of status and opportunity has been given concrete shape and form in articles 14 to 18 .
न्याय The ideals of freedom and equality are relevant and meaningful only so far as they promote the brotherhood of Indian fraternity the same son of Mother India ; it has been all the different races linguistic minorities religious and जातीय .
Provisions relating to common citizenship are directed towards strengthening Indian fraternal feelings and building a strong Indian brotherhood .
The fundamental rights guaranteed to all citizens without any discrimination and the Directive Principles directed at achieving social and economic equality are also designed to promote fraternity .
It goes beyond separation of religion and politics freedom of Hinduism equality of respect for all religions etc .
Unfortunately not enough importance has been attached by the jurists and judges to this concept .
Speaking on the need for the recognition of the principle of fraternity Dr .

No wonder that the Supreme Court found that the Preamble contained some of the basic features of the Constitution which could not be altered even by any amendment of the Constitution under article 368 .

The doctrine of classification which the courts have evolved is not नहीं of article 14 nor is it the objective and end of that code .
It is merely a judicial formula for determining whether the legislative or executive action in question is arbitrary and therefore constituting denial of equality by it .
The reasonableness of restrictions has to be determined not on abstract considerations but in an objective manner and from the point of view of persons upon whom the restrictions are imposed ( हनीफ हनीफ बिहार v. State of Bihar AIR 1958 SC प्रतिबंध ) .
It is the effect of a law which really constitutes the test of its reasonableness ; its object whether good or bad is immaterial for this purpose .

The earliest examples of the southern temple were of the unitary type consisting of the vimana single or multi - storeyed with its ardha - mandapa surrounded by the enclosure wall .
Subsequently the परिसर came a stage when a simple maha - mandapa was added in front of the ardha - mandapa and was well integrated with the main parts the prakara and the whole complex was covered by a " enclosure wall .
The circular वेसर . or apsidal from base to top or has such a plan of conduct as the griva and sikhara is वेसर .
Though in general the नागर square or oblong plan constitutes a purely Nagara form but in many cases the upper griva and sikhara of the aditala or simple or नागर series can assume octagonal or circular shapes .
Likewise the oblong structure may carry the विमान griva and sikhara . which would make the vimana विमान of the वेसर class again .
Thus more than the shape of the basal parts or structure the griva sikhara components are really important in this type of classification .
The square hexagonal circular hexagonal or octagonal structure which has a sikhara that is domical and ends up in a single finial or stupi is called kuta vimana with kuta sikhara.
The oblong and सभा body structures with a wagon - top vault - like or inverted boat - like roof or sikhara with a row of stupis on top along the ridge are known as sala vimana or विमान or sabha forms.
